revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 360 | image = 360 at his Falling and Flying CD signing.jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = 360 at his ''Falling & Flying'' CD Signing, [[Cheltenham, Victoria|Cheltenham]], February 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Matthew James Colwell | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|7|12|df=y}} | birth_place = | origin = [[Melbourne]], Victoria, Australia | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = Rapper, singer-songwriter | instrument = | years_active = 2006–present | label = Inertia, [[EMI Music Australia]], Soulmate, Forthwrite | associated_acts = Forthwrite, [[Diafrix]], [[Josh Pyke]], [[Gossling]], [[N'fa]], [[Pez (musician)|Pez]] | website = {{URL|360music.com.au}} }} '''Matthew James Colwell''' (born 12 July 1986), better known by his [[stage name]] '''360''', is an Australian [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist. He has released four studio albums: ''What You See Is What You Get'' (2008); ''[[Falling & Flying]]'' (2011), which peaked at No. 4 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] and was certified platinum; ''Utopia'' (2014), and "Vintage modern" (2017). 360's second album provided four charting singles, including "[[Boys like You (360 song)|Boys like You]]", which peaked at No. 3 on the ARIA Singles Chart and was certified 4× platinum. At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], he received six nominations and won the '[[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release|Breakthrough Artist – Release]]' award for ''Falling & Flying'', while Styalz Fuego won the ARIA 'Producer of the Year' Artisan award for the same album.{{cite web|author1=Nicholas Jones|title=360, Gotye Lead Nominations For 2012 ARIA Awards|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/208671/360-gotye-lead-nominations-2012-aria-awards.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=3 October 2012}} ==Early life== 360 was born on 12 July 1986.{{cite web | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) | title = 'Died This Way' at APRA search engine | url = http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/worksearch.axd?q=Died%20This%20Way | accessdate = 1 December 2012 }} He attended [[Luther College (Victoria)|Luther College]] in Melbourne's eastern suburbs and graduated from [[Box Hill Senior Secondary College]].{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Music== ===2003-2006: Early Career=== 360 made his first official appearance in 2003 on fellow Australian rapper Infallible's EP ''A Burning Ambition'', on the track "Situation Critical" along with MCs [[Hunter (rapper)|Hunter]] and Versa. The following year, he released his debut solo EP, titled ''Rarities'', in which three of its four tracks featured his rap partner and best friend [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]. In 2005, Pez and 360 released a song called "Nutcase", which 360 described as a "fuck around track [that was] written and recorded in one day. Trying to make you laugh, or cringe". 360 was featured on Sydney producers Weapon X and Ken Hell's 2006 mixtape ''Scar-Non III: Kick To The Head'' with the song "In Da Chub", a remix of [[50 Cent]]'s 2003 hit [[In da Club|"In Da Club"]]. ===2007–2012: ''What You See Is What You Get'', ''Falling & Flying''=== In February 2007, he signed to Soulmate Records.{{cite web|url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/artists/ |title=Soulmate Records Artist Profiles |publisher=Soulmate Records |accessdate=13 December 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |title=360 signs with Soulmate Records |publisher=Ground Up Hip-Hop |date=4 February 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921181046/http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |archivedate=21 September 2007 }} He released his debut album, ''What You See Is What You Get'', on 22 March 2008. An ''InTheMix'' reviewer found 360 "not only showcases his hilariously funny comedic side but demonstrates his ability to approach more serious and personal issues, producing a well rounded album".{{cite news | url = http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | title = 360 ''What You See Is What You Get'' Album Launch | work = InTheMix | publisher = [[Sound Alliance]] | date = 12 April 2008 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927015013/http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | archive-date = 27 September 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} In a video interview for ''Peak Street Magazine'', 360 described his musical style as a combination of "some [[pop music|pop]] influences, [[electro (music)|electro]], [[dubstep]], and unintelligent rhymes".{{cite web | last=James | first=Sam | title=360 Interview with ''Peak Street'' | url=http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131061052/http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | dead-url=yes | archive-date=31 January 2013 | work=Peak Street Magazine | accessdate=2 December 2012 | first2=Danny | last2=Haneman | first3=Aisha | last3=Glen | date=19 June 2011 }} On 14 January 2008, 360 released a music video of "Mamma Mia", which depicts his desire for [[Bec Hewitt]] and mocked her husband, [[Lleyton Hewitt]], which was the Video of the Week on MySpace.com's Australian hip hop page.{{Cite news | url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/song-slams-trophy-wife-bec/story-e6frf96x-1111115315578 | title=Rapper 360 makes Bec Hewitt lustful object of lyrics | publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times]] ([[News Corporation]]) |work=[[Herald Sun]] | date=14 January 2008 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }}{{Cite news | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/rapper-360-targets-bec-and-lleyton-hewitt-in-myspace-video/story-e6frewyr-1111115314399 | title=Rapper 360 targets Bec and Lleyton Hewitt in MySpace video | date=14 January 2008 | publisher=[[News Limited]] ([[News Corporation]]) | work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} 360 described it as a comedic effort, "I wanted to take the piss out of them ... It's not meant to be taken too seriously she's not really my type". Management for the couple dismissed the rapper's effort as "a publicity stunt". By March 2010, he remained signed with Soulmate Records, which had signed a distribution deal with [[EMI Records]].{{cite web | url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/2010/03/15/soulmate-records-x-emi-partnership// |title=Soulmate Records partners with EMI |publisher=Soulmate Records | date=15 March 2010 | accessdate=13 December 2010 }} In December that year, his single, "Just Got Started" (featuring [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]), was released.{{cite web | url = https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/just-got-started-feat.-pez/id406702982 | title = 'Just Got Started' (feat. Pez) – Single by 360 | work = [[iTunes]] | publisher = [[Apple Inc.]] | date = 17 December 2010 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} By March the following year, it peaked at No. 59 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]], and at No. 21 on the ARIA Urban Singles Chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/industry/2011/04/04/chart-wrap-up-britney-beats-radiohead-to-1/ |title=Chart Wrap Up Britney Beats Radiohead To 1 |publisher=The Music Network |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20110530-1606/Issue1099.pdf|title=The ARIA Report – 21 March 2011 |publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association |accessdate=30 March 2012}} 360's second album, ''[[Falling & Flying]]'', was released on 30 September 2011{{Cite news|url=http://www.cairns.com.au/article/2011/01/13/144105_entertainment.html|title=360 is flying and falling...|publisher=[[The Cairns Post]]|date=13 January 2011|last=Kuch|first=Jesse|accessdate=27 April 2011}} which reached No. 4 on the ARIA Albums Chart,{{cite web | url = http://www.australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and remained in the number-one position of the Australian [[iTunes]] charts for three weeks. By October 2012, ''Falling & Flying'' was certified platinum by ARIA for shipments of 70,000 units,{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and was certified double platinum by July 2014.{{cite web|author1=James Jennings|title=360: Alive and Kicking|url=http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|website=Rolling Stone Australia|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=2 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021113403/http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|archive-date=21 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In November 2011, the fourth single from the album, "Boys like You" (featuring Gossling), was released, which peaked at No. 3 on the Australian singles chart in February 2012. The track also reached the top 40 of the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]].{{cite web | url = http://charts.org.nz/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = New Zealand Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} The single was certified 4× platinum by ARIA for shipments of 280,000 units.{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=single|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} His following singles, "Child" (April 2012) and "Run Alone" (August), both reached the ARIA 'Singles Top 30' chart. "Child" was certified platinum and "Run Alone" received a gold certification. The national Australian "Flying Tour" occurred in support of the album, and 360 was supported by new Melbourne artist Bam Bam.{{cite web|title=Bam Bam|url=https://www.triplejunearthed.com/artist/bam-bam|website=triple j Unearthed|publisher=ABC|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=3 June 2013}} ===2012–present: ''Utopia'' & ''Vintage Modern''=== In June 2012, 360 revealed to national youth broadcaster [[Triple J]] that he was already working on his third album, describing the upcoming release as "quite a dark album". He described it further, "No one sees behind the scenes and there's been a lot of bad (expletive) going on in my family life and personal life". 360 hinted at a diverse production line-up for the album, saying he has "been getting a gang of beats from all different people".{{cite web|title=360 readies "dark" new album|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3518538.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=5 June 2012}} A video, published on 21 November 2013, served as the official press release for the launch of Forthwrite Records, a music label created by 360 and Pez. 360 then confirmed the announcement on his Facebook page the following day, stating that the label will release ''Don't Look Down'', by Pez, ''[[Utopia (360 album)|Utopia]]'', by 360, and the debut, yet untitled Forthwrite album.{{cite web|author1=360|title=22 November 2013|url=https://en-gb.facebook.com/3ree6ixty/posts/10153511253795367|website=360 on Facebook|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=22 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=FORTHWRITE RECORDS Media Release 21 Nov 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRkQ8OvXr3A|website=FORTHWRITE on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 November 2013}} During his performance at the 2013 Sprung Hip Hop Festival, held in [[Brisbane]], Australia, 360 garnered media attention for the manner in which he introduced a new song titled "On A Planet No One Knows". According to 360, the song, which also features a vocal sample from [[Joss Whedon]] regarding gender equality, is "about racism in Australia."{{cite web|title=WATCH: 360 – 'On A Planet No One Knows’|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/tv/watch-360-on-a-planet-no-one-knows/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014}} 360 exclaimed:
There's a lot of racist cunts in this country [Australia]. I don't know if people are proud to admit it, or what—but there is. No matter what colour or background we are, there are fuckheads in every single race. Generalising everyone is fucking ignorant and uneducated and stupid. If you're offended by this then you're probably fuckin' racist and you should fuck off.{{cite web|author1=Mike Hohnen|title=360 Calls Out Racist Australia During New Song At Sprung Hip Hop Festival|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/360-calls-out-racist-australia-during-new-song-at-sprung-hip-hop-festival/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=7 October 2013}}
In February 2014, 360 supported the Australian tour of American rapper [[Eminem]], alongside [[Kendrick Lamar]]. 360 described the tour as a career highlight and explained to the media in January 2014 that it would be his first tour sober—he had previously struggled with drug addiction.{{cite news|author1=Lisa Visentin|title=360 announces tour of Australia|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/360-announces-tour-of-australia-20140527-zrpdp.html|accessdate=20 October 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 May 2014}} Prior to the release of the artist's third album, ''Utopia'', on 13 June 2014, three singles were released: "Impossible", "On A Planet No One Knows" and "Sixavelli". "Impossible" is a collaboration with [[Daniel Johns]], of Australian band [[Silverchair]], and Johns also appears in the music video, in which he is a passenger in a car driven by 360.{{cite web|title=360 - Impossible (Ft Daniel Johns) Official Video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xU78NDpJt08|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=16 January 2014}} A music video was also released for the second single and was published on the artist's YouTube channel during the week before [[Australia Day]].{{cite web|title=360 - ON A PLANET NO ONE KNOWS|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qUWJZSbGF7s|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 January 2014}} The music video for "Sixavelli" was directed by Claudia Sangiorgi Dalimore and was published in March 2014.{{cite web|title=360 - Sixavelli (Feat. Lunar C)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IN3DtQ_aCFI&list=UUHe7RBRU1OHq0h_Yb4VTUeg|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=25 March 2014}} Alongside fellow Australian hip hop act [[Hilltop Hoods]], 360 performed at the 2014 [[Splendour In The Grass]] festival, held in [[Byron Bay]], Australia.{{cite web|title=Splendour In The Grass 2014 lineup|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3990250.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=23 April 2014}} The Australian "Utopia Tour" occurred during September 2014 and 360 was supported by US rapper Hopsin, UK artist Lunar C, Pez and Miracle.{{cite web|author1=Jed Ahern|title=360 ANNOUNCES UTOPIA TOUR SUPPORT ACTS|url=http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|website=V Music|publisher=Foxtel Management Pty Ltd|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923110500/http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|archive-date=23 September 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Collaborations== During the early years of his music career, 360 collaborated with Pez as part of a duo called "Forthwrite",{{cite web|title=ForthWrite - 'Guilty Conscience'|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDxVFtjCxyI|website=PEZ on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2011}} including a track called "The Club Song" on the 2010 album ''[[Good Gracious]]'', by producer [[M-Phazes]].{{cite web|title=Good Gracious M-Phazes|url=https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/good-gracious/id359623656|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=26 February 2010}} 360 also featured on Pez's 2008 single, "The Festival Song", which peaked at No. 14 on the ARIA Australian Singles Chart.{{cite web | url = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20090120-0000/issue985.pdf | title = ARIA Report – 12th Jan 2009 | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association | issue = 985 | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | date = 12 January 2009 | accessdate = 2 December 2012}} In 2010, 360 started an online musical project in the Australian hip hop scene, called "Rapper Tag", on YouTube.{{cite web |url=http://www.rappertag.com:80/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712043422/http://www.rappertag.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 July 2012 |title=Rapper Tag |publisher=360 |accessdate=4 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Rapper Tag involves one person recording a portion of rap over a looped beat, and then nominating ("tagging") another person to add further rapping over the same loop. The process continued in accordance with the nomination of the next rapper.{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3076379.htm |title=Triple J: 360 Rapper Tag Phenomenon |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.optimising.com.au/blog/interview-on-social-media-with-melbourne-rapper-360/|date=9 March 2011|author=Daniel |title=Interview on Social Media with Melbourne Rapper 360 |accessdate=9 March 2011}} Australian hip hop duo [[Diafrix]] collaborated with 360 for the song "I'm A Dreamer", which appears on the 2012 album ''Pocket Full Of Dreams''.{{cite web|title=Diafrix feat. 360 - I'm A Dreamer (Official Video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JXTRCDRkz34|website=diafrix lion on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2012}} 360 appeared on the self-titled debut album by Canberra producer, Ghosts in the Room, released on 14 September 2012 through Mudd Music. The album also features rappers Iron Solomon, Okwerdz and Kool G Rap.{{cite web|title=Ghosts in the Room Ghosts in the Room|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/ghosts-in-the-room/id537506609|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=14 September 2012}} ==Media appearances== 360 was a panel member for the 20 October 2014 edition of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) program ''[[Q&A (Australian talk show)|Q&A]]''. He appeared alongside [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]], a particle physicist, [[Richard Gill (conductor)|Richard Gill]], renowned conductor, and [[Nalini Joshi]], a notable Australian mathematician, to discuss the topic of "passion".{{cite web|author1=gregmoskovitch|title=Get The Popcorn, 360 Is A Panelist On Next Monday's Q&A|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/421594/360-will-appear-next-mondays-qa.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=15 October 2014}} 360 garnered media attention for his comments on the television program regarding racism in relation to Australia, Australian hip hop and the Australian flag. When questioned by the presenter, 360 replied:
On Australia Day, you see dudes walking around with their tops off, and they're getting on the drink and all that. And they've got an Australian flag wrapped around their neck. I've seen it so many times; like, I've been in a taxi where we've pulled up because these dickheads have been walking across the road—they just start yelling at the taxi driver, like: "Get out of the country! This is not your country!" ... And they're wearing Australian flags. I've seen it so much, like, growing up ... still today, you know what I mean?{{cite web|title=Australian flag represents racism: 360|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dndT4vq5CpE|website=ABC News (Australia) on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=21 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=20 October 2014}}
This response caused controversy,{{cite news|title=#BBCTrending: Has Australia's flag been co-opted by racists?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-29712614|accessdate=27 October 2014|work=BBC News|date=21 October 2014}} including the transference of the media spotlight onto Pez, who made comments on social media following 360's appearance. In addition to a message of support for his friend and musical collaborator, Pez also wrote that he also "got a bit offended"; however, he subsequently removed the sentence "To be honest, even I got a bit offended." from his original Facebook post. As of 24 October 2014, 360 had not retracted his ''Q&A'' comments and explained after the airing of the episode: "If you are not racist then you have nothing to be offended about."{{cite web|author1=Nastassia Baroni|title=Pez Admits To Being "Offended" By 360's 'Q&A' Comments|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/pez-admits-to-being-offended-by-360s-qa-comments/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=24 October 2014}} ==Personal life== {{outdated section|date=September 2016}} At the age of 18 years, 360 contracted a disease of his right eye, a [[cornea transplant]], which "left him with fuzzy vision" in that eye. A July 2014 feature article in ''Rolling Stone Australia'' stated that he is "legally blind in his right eye", while his left eye is "slowly deteriorating due to the degenerative eye disease Keratoconus". On 18 July 2010, 360 was involved in a [[go-kart]]ing accident while celebrating his birthday with Sydney-based hip hop artists [[Bliss n Eso]]. He suffered a torn [[artery]], lacerated [[pancreas]] and a damaged [[scrotum]].{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Cameron|title=Accident brings 360 perspective|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/accident-brings-360-perspective/story-e6frfn09-1226152049520|work=news.com.au| publisher = News Limited (News Corporation) | date = 29 September 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2012}} According to the rapper, "It [scrotum] wasn't ruptured, but it was ripped open ... The first thing I checked once I woke up was I didn't need to use a colostomy bag. My sex life is intact. There's no sex appeal if you use a colostomy bag". On 13 February 2012, 360 and Crystal Bale became engaged;{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Is Engaged To Crystal Bale!|url=http://www.take40.com/news/29098/rapper-360-is-engaged-to-crystal-bale!|work=take40.com|accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 Is Engaged!|url=http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|work=novafm.com.au|accessdate=18 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504133510/http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|archive-date=4 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the pair then separated on 24 December 2012.{{cite web|title=@crystallouu|url=https://twitter.com/crystallouu/status/283034663667257345|accessdate=31 December 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 degrees of separation for rapper 360 and fiancee Crystal Bale |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/degrees-of-separation-for-rapper-360-and-fiancee-crystal-bale/story-e6frewz0-1226543747857|accessdate=31 December 2012}} As of October 2014, 360 is listed as a supporter of the 'Oscar's Law' campaign, which seeks to raise public awareness about the detrimental effects of factory farming of companion animals.{{cite web|title=Home|url=http://www.oscarslaw.org/|work=Oscar's law|publisher=Oscar's Law|accessdate=13 October 2012|author=Debra Tranter|year=2010}} He also appeared in [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'s 'Ink not Mink' anti-fur campaign."[http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true Ink Not Mink! Rapper 360 Flashes His Tatts for PETA's Anti-Fur Campaign,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606033913/http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true |date=6 June 2014 }} ninemsn.com.au, 2 June 2014. 360 and Bale promoted awareness of suicide and depression issues. In mid-February 2012, he posted a video clip with the following statement: "I don't usually drop serious videos, but this is something I'm passionate about spreading awareness about. Even if you hate me, this has nothing to do with music—please share this around so as many people as possible can see it".{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Speaks Out About Suicide |url=http://www.take40.com/artists/5752/360/news/29226/watch:-rapper-360-speaks-out-about-suicide |work=take40.com |accessdate=1 December 2012 }} In September 2012, Bale posted her video, 'A Message from Crystal', which Beats Factory{{'}}s Robyn Morrison described as footage of Bale "talking about how she has been affected by suicide—multiple times ... [it] is sometimes hard to watch, but essential viewing".{{cite news | url = http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | title = 360's Fiancée Opens Up About Suicide | last = Morrison | first = Robyn | work = Beats Factory | date = 16 September 2012 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130114235912/http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | archive-date = 14 January 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} On 8 January 2016, 360 posted a song named ''I'm Sorry'' onto his [[Facebook]] page. It talked about his [[codeine]] addiction. His addiction resulted in him cancelling tours without notice. In the song 360 mentions how he didn't tell anyone because he felt like a burden. Because he was addicted to [[Nurofen Plus]], the pills could be bought without a prescription.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/melbourne-rapper-360-explains-how-prescription-drugs-almost-killed-him/news-story/1c867df0f625977f7dffcc8d63d8a08d|title=Melbourne rapper 360 explains how prescription drugs almost killed him|date=11 January 2016|access-date=16 January 2016|website=[[news.com.au]]|first1=Rohan|last1=Smith}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/music-videos/rappers-brutally-honest-painkiller-addiction-confession/news-story/b2e5a9077fe976f15716bba1630e10ee|title=Rapper’s brutally honest painkiller addiction confession|website=[[news.com.au]]|first=Emma|last=Reynolds}} In September 2016, 360 announced that he was diagnosed with [[unipolar depression]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/rapper-360s-candid-facebook-post-about-his-breakdown/news-story/0aeeb73b6e1f862c364e5e93b94d459a|title=Rapper 360 opens up about depression with heartbreaking post|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3797575/Rapper-360-reveals-struggle-unipolar-depression-heart-wrenching-essay.html|title=Rapper 360 reveals his struggle with unipolar depression.|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}} ==Accolades and awards== ===2011=== "Boys like You" was voted into the No. 8 position in the [[Triple J Hottest 100, 2011|Triple J Hottest 100 countdown of 2011]].{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/hottest100/11/fulllist.htm | title = Hottest 100 – 2011 Countdown, Full List | publisher = [[Triple J]], [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} Also that year, 360 was awarded the [[Channel V|Channel [V]]] 'Oz Artist of the Year', ahead of [[Guy Sebastian]] and [[Short Stack]],[http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ Oz Artist of the Year 2011 Entrants] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPGPChYD?url=http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ |date=14 October 2012 }}. vmusic.com.au and received the 'Jägermeister Most Hunted Award' at the [[Jägermeister]] Independent Music Awards [[Australian Independent Record Labels Association|(Australian Independent Record (AIR) Awards)]], which is voted by fans.[http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html The Winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403224000/http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html |date=3 April 2012 }}, Australian Independent Record Labels Association Ltd (AIR), 2012 ===2012=== At the 2012 AIR Awards, 360 won the 'Best Independent Hip Hop Album' award for ''Falling & Flying''.{{cite web|title=WINNERS ANNOUNCED – 2012 JAGERMEISTER INDEPENDENT MUSIC AWARDS|url=http://www.air.org.au/news/winners-announced-2012-jagermeister-independent-music-awards/|work=Australian Independent Record Labels Association|publisher=AIR|accessdate=18 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}} ===ARIA Awards=== At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], 360 was nominated in six categories and won the 'ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release' for ''Falling & Flying'', while Feugo won the 'Producer of the Year' in the Artisan section.{{Cite web revision.comment: /* ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' */clean up
revision.text:
{{short description|1956 animated horror film}} {{italic title}} <!-- Infoboxes are optional - please do not add one without discussing it on the talk page first. Thanks. --> [[File:A Short Vision title card, circa 1956.png|thumb|upright 1.17| The title card of ''A Short Vision''. ]] '''''A Short Vision''''' is a British animated film by Joan and [[Peter Foldes]] released in 1956. The film, inspired by one of Peter's poems, depicts the destruction of mankind. The film's music was composed by [[Matyas Seiber]], who composed music for ''[[Animal Farm (1954 film)|Animal Farm]]'' two years earlier.
''A Short Vision'' gained notoriety when it was shown on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' on 25 May 1956. This, however, made it controversial. Due to popular demand, it was shown again on 10 June.
==Origins== ''A Short Vision'' was inspired by a poem composed by Peter Foldes<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://conelrad.blogspot.co.uk/2011/06/short-vision-ed-sullivans-atomic-show.html|title=A SHORT VISION: Ed Sullivan’s Atomic Show Stopper|website=conelrad.blogspot.co.uk|access-date=2018-02-03}}</ref> while on a boat from Australia in October 1954. Peter was creative artist for the film,<ref name=":0" /> while his wife Joan was responsible for the [[animation stand]], the lighting and some of the animation.<ref name=":0" /> The film was produced in the Foldes' kitchen.<ref name=":0" /> and was funded by the [[British Film Institute|British Film Institute's Experimental Film Fund]].<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=BFI|title=A Short Vision (1956) {{!}} BFI National Archive|date=2009-05-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BkhNED3-mnI|accessdate=2018-02-03}}</ref> The scheme also funded an earlier Foldes' animation entitled ''Animated Genesis'' about a society which is under threat from a tyrant.<ref name=":0" />
==Synopsis== [[File:It itself, from A Short Vision.png|thumb|upright 1.17|''It'', itself.]] The film opens with a shot from a bedroom window. It pans to the sky as the narrator (James McKechnie) recalls the time he looked out his window. He saw an object flying through the sky. Throughout the film the object is only referred to as ''It''. Although ''It'' was very far away and seemed to move slowly, it came swiftly and was unnoticed. When ''It'' flew over the mountain, the leopard and the deer looked up. When they saw ''It,'' the deer ran free from the leopard's claws and they both hide in fear. When ''It'' flew over the fields, the owl and the rat looked up, and the rat ran free of the owl's claws and they both hide in fear.
When ''It'' flew over the city, everyone was asleep except for their leaders and their wise men, who all looked up at ''It,'' but it was too late. ''It'' produces a mushroom cloud engulfing the city, killing and destroying the wise men, the leaders, the owl, the leopard, the rat and the deer. ''It'' also destroys the sleeping people. ''It'' then engulfs the mountain and the fields; destroying them. When it was all over, there was nothing left except a tiny flame. Then the narrator sees ''It'' flying around the flame like a moth, and then ''It'' too is destroyed. And then, the flame died.<ref name=":1" />
==''The Ed Sullivan Show''== [[File:The mushroom cloud produced by It ; from A Short Vision.png|thumb|upright 1.17|The mushroom cloud produced by ''It.'']][[Ed Sullivan]] was originally in England when he saw ''A Short Vision''<ref name=":0" /> and promised an American showing.<ref name=":0" /> Sullivan said his motive was a "plea for peace".<ref name=":0" /> However, he may have shown it because of his relationship with George K. Arthur, the person who sold ''A Short Vision'' for the television and as well as cinemas.<ref name=":0" /> 10 days after he saw it<ref name=":0" /> on 27 May 1956, [[Ed Sullivan]] showed ''A Short Vision'' on his popular Sunday night show ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]].''<ref name=":0" /> In the first screening Sullivan told the audience to tell their children in the room to not be alarmed, because of its animated nature.<ref name=":0" /> Nevertheless, the film was controversial{{By whom|date=May 2018}}; hence, its popularity. Due to its popularity the film was shown again on 10 June. However, before showing it, Sullivan told parents to take children out of the room.<ref name=":0" />
Sullivan was incorrect{{By whom|date=May 2018}} when he first said ''A Short Vision'' depicted the effects of a [[H-Bomb]] on an "animal population".<ref name=":0" /> The film actually depicts the effects of a H-Bomb on humans and animals; not just animals.<ref name=":1" /> This leads some to believe{{Who|date=May 2018}} that he did not watch the entirety of ''A Short Vision'' before airing it on his show.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== *{{youtube|BkhNED3-mnI|A Short Vision (1956)}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Short Vision}} [[Category:Animated short films]] [[Category:Films about nuclear war and weapons]] [[Category:1956 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British animated horror films]] [[Category:Films directed by Peter Foldes]] [[Category:Films about death]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = A Single Man | image = A Single Man.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Tom Ford]] | producers = {{Plainlist| * Tom Ford * Andrew Miano * [[Robert Salerno]] * [[Chris Weitz]] }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Tom Ford * [[David Scearce]] }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[A Single Man (novel)|A Single Man]]''|[[Christopher Isherwood]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Colin Firth]] * [[Julianne Moore]] * [[Matthew Goode]] * [[Nicholas Hoult]] }} | music = [[Abel Korzeniowski]] | cinematography = Eduard Grau | editing = Joan Sobel | production companies = {{Plainlist| * Artina Films * [[Chris Weitz|Depth of Field]] * [[Tom Ford|Fade to Black]] }} | distributor = [[The Weinstein Company]] | released = {{Film date|2009|09|11|[[66th Venice International Film Festival|Venice]]|2009|12|11|United States}} | runtime = 100 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 100:33--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/single-man-film | title=''A Single Man'' (12A) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=December 11, 2009 | accessdate=October 11, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $7 million<ref>Anne Thompson (November 20, 2009). [http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/2009/11/20/a_single_man_ten_questions_for_tom_ford "Sixteen Questions for ''A Single Man''{{'}}s Tom Ford"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128061406/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/2009/11/20/a_single_man_ten_questions_for_tom_ford |date=January 28, 2010 }}. ''Indiewire''. Retrieved February 22, 2015.</ref> | gross = $25 million<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=singleman.htm |title=''A Single Man'' (2009) |work=Box Office Mojo |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=June 21, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608035935/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=singleman.htm |archivedate=June 8, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> }} '''''A Single Man''''' is a 2009 American [[Drama (modern genre)|drama film]] based on the [[A Single Man (novel)|novel of the same name]] by [[Christopher Isherwood]]. It is directed by [[Tom Ford]] in his [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]] and stars [[Colin Firth]], who was nominated for an [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] for his portrayal of George Falconer, a [[depression (mood)|depressed]] [[Homosexuality|gay]] [[British people|British]] university [[professor]] living in [[Southern California]] in 1962.
The film premiered on September 11, 2009 at the [[66th Venice International Film Festival]], and went on the film festival circuit. After it screened at the [[2009 Toronto International Film Festival|34th Toronto International Film Festival]], [[The Weinstein Company]] picked it up for distribution in the United States and Germany. An initial [[Limited release|limited run]] in the United States commenced on December 11, 2009, to qualify it for the [[82nd Academy Awards]] with a [[Wide release|wider release]] in early 2010.<ref name="Variety.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118008654.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |title=Weinsteins engage ''Single Man'' |accessdate=December 3, 2009 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |first=Michael |last=Fleming |first2=Sharon |last2=Swart |date=September 14, 2009}}</ref>
== Plot == On November 30, 1962, a month after the [[Cuban missile crisis]], George Falconer is a middle-aged English college professor living in Los Angeles. George dreams that he encounters the body of his longtime partner, Jim, at the scene of the car accident that took Jim's life eight months earlier. He bends down to kiss his dead lover. After awakening, George delivers a voiceover discussing the pain and depression he has endured since Jim's death and his intention to commit suicide that evening.
George receives a phone call from his dearest friend, Charley, who projects lightheartedness despite her also being miserable. George goes about his day putting his affairs in order and focusing on the beauty of isolated events, believing he is seeing things for the last time. At times, he recalls his sixteen-year-long relationship with Jim.
During the school day George comes into contact with a student, Kenny Potter, who shows interest in George and disregards conventional boundaries of student-professor discussion. George also forms an unexpected connection with a Spanish male prostitute, Carlos. That evening George meets Charley for dinner. Though they initially reminisce and amuse themselves by dancing, Charley's desire for a deeper relationship with George and her failure to understand his relationship with Jim angers George.
George goes to a bar and discovers that Kenny has followed him. They get a round of drinks, go skinny dipping, and then return to George's house and continue drinking. George passes out and wakes up in bed with Kenny asleep in another room. While watching Kenny, George discovers that he had fallen asleep holding George's gun, to keep George from committing suicide. George locks the gun away, burns his suicide notes and in a voiceover explains that he has rediscovered the ability "to feel, rather than think". As he makes peace with his grief, George suffers a heart attack and dies, while envisioning Jim appearing and kissing him.
== Cast == {{Cast listing| * [[Colin Firth]] as George Falconer * [[Julianne Moore]] as Charlotte (Charley) * [[Nicholas Hoult]] as Kenny Potter * [[Matthew Goode]] as Jim * [[Jon Kortajarena]] as Carlos * Paulette Lamori as Alva * [[Ryan Simpkins]] as Jennifer Strunk * [[Ginnifer Goodwin]] as Mrs. Strunk * [[Teddy Sears]] as Mr. Strunk * Paul Butler as Christopher Strunk * Aaron Sanders as Tom Strunk * [[Lee Pace]] as Grant Lefanu * [[Erin Daniels]] as Bank Teller * [[Aline Weber]] as Lois }}
[[Jon Hamm]] has an uncredited voice cameo as Harold Ackerly. He is Jim's cousin, who calls George to tell him of Jim's death.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lane|last=Brown|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2009/12/don_draper_revealed_as_bearer.html|title=Don Draper Revealed as ''Single Man''{{'}}s Bearer of Bad News|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|publisher=[[New York Media]]|location=New York City|date=December 10, 2009|accessdate=February 22, 2015}}</ref>
== Production == Fashion designer [[Tom Ford]], as a first-time director, financed the film himself.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tom Ford: Design Director |first=Laura M. |last=Holson |date=December 2, 2009 |accessdate=December 3, 2009 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/03/fashion/03ford.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501193103/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/03/fashion/03ford.html |archivedate=May 1, 2011<!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> The film places emphasis on the culture of the 1960s; the production design is by the same team that designed AMC television's ''[[Mad Men]]'', which is set in the same era. ''Mad Men'' star [[Jon Hamm]] has an uncredited voice cameo as the cousin of George's partner, Jim.<ref name="E!Online">{{cite web |url=http://au.eonline.com/uberblog/marc_malkin/b30780_tom_ford_looking_single_some_mad_men.html |title=Tom Ford Looking to Single Out Some Mad Men |first=Marc |last=Malkin |date=September 24, 2008 |accessdate=December 2, 2009 |work=[[E! Online]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215093910/http://au.eonline.com/uberblog/marc_malkin/b30780_tom_ford_looking_single_some_mad_men.html |archivedate=December 15, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> The actual house where the character George lives in the film was designed in 1948 by [[John Lautner]], his first house after leaving [[Frank Lloyd Wright]].<ref>According to Tom Ford's director commentary on the DVD. Retrieved October 10, 2010.</ref>
The film was shot in 21 days, according to "The Making of ''A Single Man''" on the DVD.
== Marketing controversy == An early theatrical poster for ''A Single Man'' featured a close-up shot of Colin Firth and Julianne Moore lying side by side, their arms and shoulders touching. This led to speculation that the work's gay content and themes were being deleted or diminished in its marketing materials to improve its chances of success with a wider audience. A new poster with Moore relocated to the background was issued. The film's original trailer placed more emphasis on the relationship between George and Jim but a re-cut trailer omitted a shot of George and Jim kissing while retaining a kiss between George and Charley. Also deleted were a shot of George staring into a male student's eyes, while keeping a shot of George staring into the eyes of a female student, shots of George meeting hustler Carlos outside a liquor store, and shots of George and Kenny running nude into the ocean.<ref name="Indie">{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/a_tale_of_two_trailers_the_de-gaying_of_a_single_man/# |title=A Tale of Two Trailers: The De-Gaying of ''A Single Man'' |work=Indiewire |date=October 26, 2012 |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
Speaking of the controversy, Moore said that director Tom Ford expressed concern that the original poster made the film appear to be a romantic comedy and that he ordered that the poster be changed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbook.com/film/julianne-moore-on-the-de-gaying-of-a-single-man/ |title=Julianne Moore on the De-Gaying of ''A Single Man'' |work=[[BlackBook]] |date=February 3, 2010 |accessdate=August 27, 2015}}</ref> However Ford, noting he does not see the film in terms of gay or straight, said, "I don't think the movie's been de-gayed. I have to say that we live in a society that's pretty weird. For example, you can have full-frontal male nudity on HBO, yet in cinema, you can't have naked male buttocks. You can't have men kissing each other without it being considered adult content. So, in order to cut a trailer that can go into broad distribution in theaters, certain things had to be edited out. But it wasn't an intentional attempt to remove the gayness of the movie."<ref>{{cite news |last=Shapiro |first=Gregg |url=http://www.ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=film&article=704 |title=A singular man |work=Ebar |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref> Conversely, Colin Firth said, "[The marketing] is deceptive. I don't think they should do that because there's nothing to sanitize. It's a beautiful story of love between two men and I see no point in hiding that. People should see it for what it is."<ref>{{cite news|last=Voss |first=Brandon |url=http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/Film/Men_Behind_A_Single_Man/Colin_Firth_Singled_Out |title=Colin Firth: Singled Out |work=Advocate |date=December 9, 2009 |accessdate=December 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100711053025/http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/Film/Men_Behind_A_Single_Man/Colin_Firth_Singled_Out/ |archivedate=July 11, 2010 }}</ref> [[Harvey Weinstein]] would only say, when asked about marketing a gay romance, "''Brokeback Mountain'' did pretty well. ''Midnight Cowboy'' did pretty well. If you know how to market, you can market. There's an audience for it." When pressed about the poster, Weinstein cut off the interview, saying, "I'm good. You got enough. Thank you."<ref>{{cite news |last=Vilensky |first=Mike |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2009/11/harvey_weinstein_explains_a_si.html |title=Harvey Weinstein Explains ''A Single Man''{{'}}s Marketing, Sort of |work=NYMag.com |date=November 7, 2013 |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref> Peter Knegt of ''[[Indiewire]]'' suggested that The Weinstein Company "de-gayed" the trailer to better the film's chances of receiving [[Academy Award]] nominations.<ref name="Indie" />
== Reception ==
=== Critical response === [[File:ASingleManCastVenice66.jpg|thumb|right|alt=66th Venice Film Festival, 10th day (September 11, 2009).|Red carpet with Matthew Goode, Tom Ford, Julianne Moore, Colin Firth, Nicholas Hoult and Jon Kortajarena at [[66th Venice Film Festival]].]]
The film has received an overall positive reception from critics, with most reviews singling out Colin Firth's performance. It currently holds an 85% "Fresh" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 175 reviews, with the site's consensus being that "Though the costumes are beautiful and the art direction impeccable, what stands out most from this debut by fashion designer Tom Ford is the leading performance by Colin Firth."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.rottentomatoes.com/m/1218217-single_man |title=''A Single Man'' (2009) |work=Rotten Tomatoes |publisher=Flixter |accessdate=December 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709014029/http://au.rottentomatoes.com/m/1218217-single_man/ |archivedate=July 9, 2010 }}</ref> [[Metacritic]] has compiled an average score of 77 (generally favorable reviews) from 35 critic reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/singleman |title=''A Single Man'' (2009) |work=Metacritic |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=December 1, 2011}}</ref>
Michael Phillips of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' wrote "Some films aren’t revelations, exactly, but they burrow so deeply into old truths about love and loss and the mess and thrill of life, they seem new anyway"<ref name="Ryll2014">{{cite web |author=Alexander Ryll |year=2014 |title=Essential Gay Themed Films To Watch, ''A Single Man'' |work=Gay-Themed-Films.com |publisher=Gay Essential |accessdate=December 22, 2014 |url=http://gay-themed-films.com/films-to-watch-a-single-man}}</ref> Bob Mondello of [[NPR]] commented “An exquisite, almost sensual grief suffuses every frame of A Single Man.”<ref name="Ryll2014" /> Marc Savlov of ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' wrote “Everything fits perfectly, from titles to fin, but most of all Colin Firth, who dons the role of George like a fine bespoke suit.”<ref name="Ryll2014" />
Critics who liked the film include ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' film critic Nathan Rabin, who gave the film an A- score, arguing that "''A Single Man'' is a film of tremendous style wedded to real substance, and rooted in "Firth's affecting lead performance as a man trying to keep it together for one last day after his world has fallen apart."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/a-single-man,36227 |title=''A Single Man'' review |first=Nathan |last=Rabin |date=December 10, 2009 |work=A. V. Club |accessdate=December 19, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213132758/http://www.avclub.com/articles/a-single-man%2C36227/ |archivedate=December 13, 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Critic [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' also praised Firth, saying that he "plays George superbly, as a man who prepares a face to meet the faces that he meets. He betrays very little emotion, and certainly his thoughts cannot be read in his eyes."<ref>{{cite news |last=Ebert |first=Roger |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091223/REVIEWS/912239995 |title=''A Single Man'' review |work=Chicago Sun-Times |publisher=RogerEbert.com |date=December 23, 2009 |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref>
''[[The Times]]'' newspaper of London called the film "a thing of heart-stopping beauty . . . There will be critics who will be unable to get past the director's background, but rest assured: Tom Ford is the real deal."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/film_reviews/article6830518.ece |location=London |work=The Times |first=Wendy |last=Ide |title=''A Single Man'' at Venice Film Festival |date=September 11, 2009}}</ref> [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]'s verdict: "Luminous and treasurable, despite its imperfections. An impressive helming debut for fashion designer Tom Ford."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117941020.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 |work=Variety |first=Leslie |last=Felperin |title=''A Single Man'' |date=September 11, 2009}}</ref>
== Accolades == The film was nominated for the [[Golden Lion]] at the [[66th Venice International Film Festival]] and won the festival's third annual [[Queer Lion 2009|Queer Lion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=4526&MediaType=1&Category=27 |title=Gay Entertainment Report: Ford's ''Single Man'' Wins Queer Lion |work=OnTopMag.com |date=September 12, 2009 |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref> Colin Firth was awarded the [[Volpi Cup]] for Best Actor at the film festival for his performance in the film.<ref name="Labiennale">{{cite web |url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/cinema/festival/premi |title=66th Venice International Film Festival Official Awards |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |work=Labiennale.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091006165644/http://www.labiennale.org/en/cinema/festival/premi |archivedate=October 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He received a [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] for [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor in a Leading Role]].<ref name="BAFTA.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/film-awards-nominations,949,BA.html#jump9 |title=63rd British Academy Film Awards – Leading Actor |accessdate=February 21, 2010 |work=BAFTA.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323165515/http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/film-awards-nominations%2C949%2CBA.html#jump9 |archivedate=March 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Firth also received [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe]], [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role|Screen Actors Guild]] and [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Academy Award]] nominations for Best Actor. For her performance, Julianne Moore was nominated for a Golden Globe Award for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture|Best Supporting Actress in Motion Picture]]. Abel Korzeniowski was nominated for a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score]]. The film received the [[Grand Prix (Belgian Syndicate of Cinema Critics)|Grand Prix]] from the [[Belgian Syndicate of Cinema Critics]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.moniteurdufilm.be/?article=69&PHPSESSID=d0636412b8c21fa5e4cc15a80ae5ad53 |title=''A Single Man'', Grand Prix 2011 de l'UCC |work=Moniteur du film |accessdate=January 9, 2012 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017144132/http://www.moniteurdufilm.be/?article=69&PHPSESSID=d0636412b8c21fa5e4cc15a80ae5ad53 |archivedate=October 17, 2012 }}</ref>
On January 14, 2010, the film was nominated for, and later won, [[GLAAD Media Award for Outstanding Film – Wide Release|Outstanding Film – Wide Release]] at the [[21st GLAAD Media Awards]] along with AFI's Film of the Year.<ref name="GLAAD.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/21/nominees |title=21st Annual GLAAD Media Awards – English Language Nominees |accessdate=January 14, 2010 |work=GLAAD.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117085103/http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/21/nominees |archivedate=January 17, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1315981/awards]</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist |name = Asmahan
أسمهان |background = solo_singer |image = Asmahan1.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Amal al-Atrash
آمال الأطرش |alias = |birth_date = November 25, 1912 |birth_place = [[Mediterranean Sea]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1944|7|14|1912|11|25}} |death_place = [[Mansoura]], [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]] |genre = [[Arabic music]] |occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[actor]] |instrument = |years_active = |label = |associated_acts = [[Farid al-Atrash]] |website = }} '''Amal al-Atrash''' ({{lang-ar|آمال الأطرش}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Āmāl al-Aṭrash}}''; November 25, 1912 – July 14, 1944),[http://almadapaper.net/paper.php?source=akbar&mlf=interpage&sid=64405 "منزل الفنانة أسمهان بات متحفاً"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130111235017/http://almadapaper.net/paper.php?source=akbar&mlf=interpage&sid=64405 |date=2013-01-11 }}, ''Al-Mada'' better known by her stage name '''Asmahan''' ({{lang|ar|أسمهان}} ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Asmahān}}''), was a [[Syrian people|Syrian]] born{{cite book|author=Samy Swayd|title=Historical Dictionary of the Druzes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eL0qBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA57|date=10 March 2015|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4422-4617-1|page=57}} singer who lived in [[Egypt]]. Having immigrated to [[Egypt]] at the age of three years old, her family knew the composer [[Dawood Hosni]], and she sang the compositions of [[Mohamed El Qasabgi]] and [[Zakariyya Ahmad]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lebarmy.gov.lb/article.asp?ln=ar&id=8358|title=Lebanese Army Journal, Issue Number 241, July 2005|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111224421/http://www.lebarmy.gov.lb/article.asp?ln=ar&id=8358|archive-date=2013-11-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}al-Atrash, Majid (2005), Asmahan: Amirat at-tarab was-saif wan-nada (Asmahan: The princess of music, war and grace) al-'Adyat magazine, p.75–77, in Arabic She also sang the compositions of [[Mohammed Abdel Wahab]] and her brother [[Farid al-Atrash]], a then rising star musician in his own right. Her voice was one of the few female voices in Arab music world to pose serious competition to that of [[Umm Kulthum]],{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=85}} who is considered to be one of the Arab world's most distinguished singers of the 20th century.[http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/Story.aspx?sid=1301 Prominent Egyptians - Egyptian Government State Information Service] Her mysterious death in an automobile accident shocked the public. Journalists spread gossip about her turbulent personal life and an alleged [[espionage]] role in [[World War II]]. == Early life == Asmahan was born to Fahd al-Atrash, a [[Syria]]n [[Druze]] from [[As-Suwayda|Suwayda]], and 'Alia al-Mundhir, a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] Druze from [[Hasbaya]].{{Harvnb|Zuhur|1998|p=81}} Her father came from the Druze [[al-Atrash]] [[clan]], well known in Syria for its role in fighting against the [[French mandate of Syria|French]] occupation.{{Citation|last=Provence|first=Michael |title=The great Syrian revolt and the rise of Arab nationalism|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=2005|edition=illustrated|pages=72|isbn=978-0-292-70680-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ej8ZMk1822sC&pg=PA72&dq=sultan+al+atrash}} Asmahan's father supposedly served as governor of the district of [[Demirci]] in [[Turkey]], during the last days of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. Asmahan's father, fled the country with his children and pregnant wife. On 25 November 1912, they embarked on a ship from [[İzmir]] to [[Beirut]], and Asmahan was born on board. She was named "Amal", meaning "hopes". She was also called "Emily", but always preferred the name "Amal". After the French came into power, the family returned to [[Jabal al-Druze (state)|Jabal al-druze]]. Following the [[Adham Khanjar|Adham Khanjar incident]] in 1922, the al-Atrash home in [[al-Qurayya|al-Qrayya]] (a town in [[Jabal al-Druze]]) was bombed by French forces. 'Alia fled with her children to [[Damascus]] and, despite orders from Fahd, refused to return.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|pp=38}} Asmahan later recalled her childhood years in Jabal al-Druze as "untouched by anything truly bad".{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=36}} 'Alia and the three children travelled to [[Beirut]], but, after discovering that the French were searching for them there, they stopped in [[Haifa]] in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], and travelled from there to Egypt, where she sought Political Asylum for her and her three children; they were later granted the right of Political Asylum in 1926 by the Egyptian Government, thus naturalized as Egyptian citizens.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|pp=38–39}} ===Immigration to Egypt=== [[File:Aleya Al Menzer and her Children.jpg|thumb|right|'Alia and her children after arrival in Egypt]] 'Alia chose to immigrate to [[Cairo]], because 'Alia knew that Egypt's then [[nationalist]] prime minister [[Saad Zaghloul]] and her husband's relative, [[Sultan al-Atrash]] were on corresponding terms.{{YouTube|WoFmMGNOxLs|Interview with Fuad al-Atrash. Time 4:34.}}{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=39}} According to family accounts, 'Alia was permitted to enter Egypt under the sponsorship of Saad Zaghloul. Many other Syrians and Lebanese were present in Egypt in this period. Asmahan and her family first lived in an apartment in a humble section of Cairo. Her mother did laundry and sewing to support the family.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=41}} She had an excellent voice, could play the [[Oud|`ud]], sang at parties and made some recordings. Asmahan and her brothers attended a French Catholic school. In order to receive waivers for the high cost of tuition, 'Alia registered them under the alias ''Kusah'' (meaning "courgette") rather than trying to convince school officials that members of the wealthy{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} al-Atrash family were destitute.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|pp=41, 53}} 'Alia received a monthly stipend from a secret benefactor rumored to be [[Charles Richard Crane|"Baron" Crane]] (of the [[King–Crane Commission]]) according to one Egyptian journalist. This allowed her to cover the costs of her children's school's tuition, and a nicer apartment on Habib Shalabi Street.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|pp=42, 44}} ==Career== ===Musical debut=== [[File:Farid Asmahan.jpg|thumb|Asmahan and her brother Farid]] Amal's vocal talent was discovered at an early age. Once, when her brother Farid received one of Egypt's most famous composers, Dawood Hosni, in their home, the latter overheard her singing in her room, and insisted on seeing her immediately. He then asked her to sing again. He was much impressed by the performance, and suggested the stage name of Asmahan to her. Amal began using that name. Asmahan rose to fame quickly: she was not even fourteen (or seventeen, since her birth date is disputed) years old when she was introduced to the public at a concert at the prestigious [[Cairo Opera House]].{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/utpress/excerpts/exzuhasp.html|title=University of Texas Press|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2016}} She sang and recorded songs composed by Farid Ghosn, Dawood Hosni, Mohamed El Qasabgi, and Zakariyya Ahmad. At sixteen, Asmahan was invited by an Egyptian record company to make her first album, featuring her first song "Ya Nar Fouadi" by Farid Ghosn. A variety of teachers advanced her vocal and musical studies. Hosni volunteered to instruct Asmahan on how to play the [[oud]]; Qasabgi comments however on the mature level of her sight reading and musicality by the time she performed his work, some years later. However, her brothers wanted her to marry and return to Syria. Her cousin, Hassan al-Atrash travelled to Egypt, intending to propose to a different relative, however, once he saw Asmahan, he pursued her and she returned to Syria for at least five and half years, interrupting her musical career. ===Egypt's influence=== Since Asmahan sang in Egypt, the lyrics of her songs were written in classical Arabic and in a more colloquial Arabic, but she also sang in the Eastern dialect of Arabic. Asmahan was particularly fond of performing songs by [[Umm Kulthoum]] and [[Mohamed Abdel Wahab]].{{Harvnb|Al-Taba'i|2008|p=82}}{{Harvnb|Al-Taba'i|2008|p=26}} When asked to sing about cultural patriotism and love, she sang of Egypt."{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=216}} Since singers and studios depended on the elites, Asmahan had to sing songs on uplifting nationalist themes or in praise of the Egyptian royal family.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=13}} At the beginning of her career she sang in the nightclub owned by Mary Mansour. Asmahan's older brother, Fuad, and other Druze relatives considered a career in entertainment for a girl to be disgraceful.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|1998|p=82}} For them, culturally, "Egypt was a planetary distance from the small villages of the Druze."{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=54}} and it was difficult for her relatives to accept Asmahan's integration into the heterogeneous Egyptian social scene. The clearly defined divisions, along religious lines, of the Syrian countryside did not operate in Egypt. During the period when she was married to her cousin, Hassan, and then later in 1941, when she remarried him and returned to Egypt her musical career came to a standstill. When the marriage first broke up, she left for Egypt immediately, even before she had obtained the bill of divorce. With her return to Egypt and a singing career, she finally repudiated "respectability", leaving both her relatives and Syrian Druze society furious. When her first film, ''Intisar al-Shabab'', was released in Syria, one young Druze shot at the screen when the character played by Asmahan appeared.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=98}} Asmahan, bi-national or, in contemporary parlance, trans-national by then, had become "a sophisticated ''foreigner'' to the young men in the Jabal Druze."{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=95}} ==Personal life== In 1933 Asmahan's cousin, [[Hassan al-Atrash]], came to Cairo and proposed marriage, requesting that Asmahan abandon her musical career.{{Harvnb|Al-Taba'i|2008|p=51}} She agreed on three conditions: that they live in Damascus rather than [[Jabal al-Druze]], winter in Cairo, and that she would never be required to wear the traditional [[hijab]].{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ydFpAAAAMAAJ|title=Steel and Silk|first=Sami M.|last=Moubayed|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Cune Press, LLC|accessdate=5 August 2016|via=Google Books}} They married and moved first to [[Ira, Syria|'Ara]] where the al-Atrash retain a large home, and then built their own home in Suwayda. Asmahan gave birth to her daughter, Kamellia. Eventually, Asmahan missed her career and her life in Cairo;{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|pp=69–70}} and in 1939, she and Hassan were divorced. In her final confrontation with her cousin at [[Mena House Oberoi|Mena House]] Hotel in [[Giza]], she told him, "I stood with you for independence and liberation, I did. But, I was created for another purpose. I prefer the work of Farid, and the work of Umm Kulthum, and of art."{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=99}} She returned to Cairo and resumed her singing career, entering a short marriage to Egyptian director [[Ahmed Badrkhan]]. In 1941 she returned to Syria in a dramatic and secret journey under the auspices of the British. Hassan agreed to meet with her, and used the occasion to successfully entreat her to remarry him. During the time they were married, she twice attempted suicide. Tabloid newspapers suggested that this was so that she could obtain a second divorce from Hassan; however it seemed he actually agreed due to her visits to Jerusalem where wild rumours attached to her behaviour and overspending. Her third and final marriage was to the Egyptian director [[Ahmed Salem]], supposedly to facilitate her return to Egypt over impositions by government authorities. It is unclear how that would occur, however, and she had an ongoing studio contract in Egypt. Asmahan was close friends with the al Othman family and met with them when she travelled to Haifa, Palestine, when they helped her. Also in 1941, Asmahan met Mohammed Abdel Wahab, Egypt's most distinguished singer and composer, and starred with him in his operetta ''Magnun Layla'' ("''Besotted with Layla''").[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/933/ee2.htm Baraka, Mohamed. Al-Ahram Weekly. Issue #933. 2009-02-05.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725070959/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/933/ee2.htm |date=July 25, 2009 }} Abdel Wahab introduced her to the journalist, Mohamed al-Taba'i, who suggests that she was in love with him, but the tone of his writing indicates that he was in love with her, but did not respect her. He suggests she had affairs or at least an ongoing relationship with the royal chamberlain [[Ahmed Hassanein|Ahmed Pasha Hassanein]] but this might be exaggerated. Her brothers, Fuad and Farid, were no longer able to monitor her movements. Her brother was a noted gambler; she and her friends also partied, smoked, drank and gambled. She became very ill for a period, but recordings show that her voice did not suffer. Asmahan was proud of her family background, and always mentioned her father and his cousin, [[Sultan al-Atrash]], to clarify her ancestry — once saying to al-Taba'i, after he had just insulted her, "Don't you know who I am? Why I am the daughter of Fahd al-Atrash and cousin to the Amir al-Atrash and the Druze revolutionary hero Sultan al-Atrash.{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=37}}{{Harvnb|Al-Taba'i|2008|pp=108–109}} Asmahan was not a first cousin of Hassan's, but referred to him as "ibn 'ammi" to the Egyptians, in fact, she was his second cousin, twice removed (by generation). == Vocal characteristics == {{Original research section|date=July 2009}} [[File:Asmahan photo.jpg|thumb|220x220px|Asmahan]] Asmahan's noted wide vocal range included [[contralto]] and dramatic [[mezzo-soprano]] (as one can hear in her rendition of "Ya Tuyur" where she reaches a high A with ease and brio). Asmahan's voice has been compared to Fairuz and Sabah. However, as she began her career more than two decades earlier, she had not in fact, adopted the Italian singing technique known as [[bel canto]], but rather learned singing from many admirable models of her own period and in Egypt where a much more diverse group of singers performed, and at a time when Arabic singing utilized both nasal and chest resonance. Asmahan's voice was powerful, but also agile. She generally sang in her chest register but could use her head register and sing in a very controlled tone. It is not incorrect to say that she was the first or one of the first Arabic singers to use the classical western technique, also very few performers are able to alternate two different styles of interpretation and technique in one song (western and arab).Zuhur == Role in World War II == In 1941, during [[World War II]], Asmahan returned to the [[French Mandate of Syria]] (Syria, then under the rule of [[Vichy France]]) at the request of the British and the Free French. She was on a secret mission to notify her people in Jabal al-Druze that the [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Free French forces]] would be invading [[Syria]] through their territory, and to convince them they should not fight. The British and Free French had promised the independence of Syria and Lebanon to all inhabitants on the date of the invasion. The [[Druze]] agreed, even though some groups did not receive word in time and fought the invading forces. After the Allies secured [[Syria]] during the [[Syria-Lebanon campaign|Syria-Lebanon Campaign]], General [[Charles de Gaulle]] visited Syria. When the Allies failed to carry out their promise for Syrian independence, Asmahan tried to contact the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] in Turkey, but was stopped at the border and sent to Lebanon. It was also possible that Asmahan needed money because her husband had cut off her expenses, so she may have tried to reach the Germans simply to obtain funds. Asmahan told Mohamed al-Taba'i that she was to receive the sum of £40,000 from the British for her services to the allies.{{Harvnb|Al-Taba'i|2008|pp=142–146}}{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=115}}''[[al-Raida]]'', Beirut University College, Institute for Women's Studies in the Arab World, [https://books.google.com/books?id=cSAqAAAAYAAJ&q=asmahan+nazli&dq=asmahan+nazli p.42.] General [[Charles de Gaulle]]'s representative in Cairo was General [[Georges Catroux]]. Catroux's délégué in Damascus, Colonel Collet, stated that the British gave money to Asmahan (and to other Druze men, in his presence) and sent her to the Jabal to secure the support of the Druze before the Allies' invasion.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9NvPEnnpsnwC|title=Syria's Quest for Independence, 1939-1945|first=Salma Mardam|last=Bey|date=1 September 1997|publisher=Ithaca|accessdate=5 August 2016|via=Google Books}} The same information is stated by [[Edward Spears]] in his memoirs. == Death == On 14 July 1944, a car carrying Asmahan and a female friend crashed and went into a canal at the side of the road, after the driver lost control near the city of [[Mansoura]], Egypt. The car was a two-door model and the women were sitting in the backseat. They were presumed to be rendered unconscious and subsequently drowned. The driver, however, managed to escape. These circumstances gave rise to many suspicions, rumours and conspiracy theories. British intelligence, for example, after many reports circulated claiming she had been working for them, was accused of having got rid of her after she had attempted to meet with German agents. The German [[Gestapo]] was also accused of murdering her for the help she had given the British. Her husband at the time had fought violently with her, and her family's honour had been besmirched by the many rumours. Asmahan was buried in Egypt in accordance with her wishes{{Harvnb|Zuhur|2000|p=165}} as, years later, were her two brothers, Fouad and [[Farid al-Atrash]],[http://www.classicalarabicmusic.com/fareed_al_atrach.htm Classical Arabic Music Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912032423/http://www.classicalarabicmusic.com/fareed_al_atrach.htm |date=2010-09-12 }} in the [[Fustat|Fustat plain]] in Cairo, which she and brother Farid, along with Egyptian crooner [[Abdel Halim Hafez]],[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/943/ee1.htm Baraka, Mohamed. Al-Ahram Newspaper Article. Issue No. 943, 16 - 22 April 2009.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809041701/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/943/ee1.htm |date=August 9, 2009 }} had restored to some of its former glory.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7OJ0-tXE_9MC&pg=PA96&dq=%22farid%20al-atrash%22%20buried%20egypt|title=Architecture for the Dead : Cairo's Medieval Necropolis|first1=Galila El|last1=Kadi|first2=Alain|last2=Bonnamy|date=1 January 2007|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|accessdate=5 August 2016|via=Google Books}} == Legacy == The [[Egyptian Media Production City]] and a private investor jointly produced a television series depicting the life (and death) of Asmahan.{{cite web|url=http://thawra.alwehda.gov.sy/_print_veiw.asp?FileName=45775321720080802231457|title=صحيفة الثورة|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2016}} The Arabic series debuted during the month of Ramadan in 2008. Asmahan was played by Syrian actress [[Sulaf Fawakherji]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/|title=Homepage|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2016}} On 25 November 2015, Google celebrated Asmahan's 103rd birthday using a Google doodle.{{cite web|title=Asmahan’s 103rd Birthday|url=https://www.google.com/doodles/asmahans-103rd-birthday|website=Google|accessdate=25 November 2015}} ==Discography== {{Expand section|date=September 2009}} {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} *Eedy fi Eedak *Shorouq we Ghoroub *al-Khitam Operette (from the movie Intisar Al Shabab) *al-Layl *as-Shams Ghabat Anwarha *ad-Denya fi Eedy *al-Osra al-Alaweyya Anthem (from the movie Gharam wa Intiqam) *Aamel Eah Ashan Ansak? *Ana Bent al-Layl *Ghayra Magd Poem *Hadaytak Alby *Adhaby fi Hawak Ardaah *Hal Tayyem al-Ban {{col-3}} *Isqineeha bi Aby Anta wa Ommy *Ahwa *Emta Hatearaf? *Ana elly Astahel *Ayna al-Layaly? *Ayyuha Anna'em *Hadeath Aynayn *Dakhalt Marra fi Genenah *Regeaat Lak *Aahedny ya Alby *Alek Salat Allah we Salamoh *Farraq ma Benna az-Zamaan *Fi yom Mashoofak *Magnoon Layla {{col-3}} *Kan li Amal *Kelma ya Nour al-Ain *Konty al-Amany *Layaly al-Ons fi Vienna {{YouTube|pCR7KGNkcfM|"Asmahan performs Layaly al-Ons fi Vienna"}} *Layta lel-Bouraq Ayna *Mahlaha Eishet al-Fallah *Nawayt Adary Aalaamy *al-Ward *Ya Habibi Allah *Ya Dirati *Ya Toyour (or Taghreed al-Balabel) *Yally Hawak *Ya Layali al-Bishr *Ya Naar Fouadi {{col-end}} ==Filmography== * ''Intissar al-Shabab'' ("''Triumph of the Youth''"), 1941 * ''Gharam wa Intiqam'' ("''Love and Revenge''"), 1944 ==References== *{{citation|last=Zuhur|first=Sherifa |title=Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music and the Visual Arts of the Middle East|publisher=American University in Cairo Press|year=2001|isbn=977-424-607-1|ref=CITEREFZuhur2001}} ==External links== {{Portal|Egypt|Syria|Biography|Film|Music}} {{Commons category|Asmahan}} * {{IMDb name|0039543}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120507092858/http://asmahan.com/ Asmahan fan site] * [http://www.utexas.edu/utpress/excerpts/exzuhasp.html Introduction to ''Asmahan's Secrets''], a biography ({{ISBN|978-0-292-79807-6}}) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Asmahan}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:People born at sea]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]]
