revision.text:
{{Cleanup rewrite|date=September 2016}}
'''Guilt-free consumption''' (GFC) is a pattern of [[Consumption (sociology)|consumption]] based on the minimization of the sense of [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]] which consumers incur when purchasing products or commercial services.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://trendwatching.com/trends/guiltfreeconsumption/|title=Guilt-Free Consumption|last=Izzo|first=John|date=November 2013|website=trendwatching.com|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
The spread of [[ethical consumerism]], and the following availability of information about the ethicality of products, can be understood as the driving force of guilt free consumption.<ref name=":0" /> In this sense, the feeling of guilt experienced by consumers is fostered by their knowledge of the potential consequences of their choices. The tension between consumers' values and the awareness that their actions may run counter to those same values, manifests itself as a potent, nagging guilt.
Consumers are therefore induced to prefer those companies which are able to offer sustainable practices and products in order to minimize their sense of guiltiness.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/john-izzo/guilt-free-consumption_b_6140182.html|title=Businesses Need To Start Focusing on 'Guilt-Free' Consumption To Get Ahead.|last=Izzo|first=John|date=11 November 2014|website=Huff Post|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Areas of concern == GFC is concerned with three main dimensions<ref name=":1" /> in which the sense of guilt arises: * self: guilt about one's impact on oneself or on their family, e.g. people worrying about their physical and mental well-being. * society and nature: guilt about social impact, including damages directly and indirectly caused to other people (and other living creatures), e.g. people worrying about poor working conditions, sub-poverty wages and exploitation. * planet: guilt about environmental impact e.g. people worrying about wasteful packaging, CO<sub>2</sub> emissions, rainforest destruction. However, there is a fourth dimension that mainly affect newly minted urban consumers: the so-called "cultural-guilt";<ref name=":0" /> the feeling of culpability caused by the split between global and traditional consumption, e.g. people worrying about the abandoning of their identity in favor of [[globalization]] (globalized culture of consumerism).
A totally guilt free consumption is almost impossible to achieve, since products or servicing reducing guilt on one dimension, might foster the same negative feeling on an other; as a consequence GFC aims at the minimization of guilt rather than striving for a complete deletion.
== Guilt and the divided self == Guilt arises when individuals fail in meeting their own personal self-standards or when a conflict among what the theory of discrepancy calls "selves", emerges.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Peloza|first=John|date=January 2013|title=Good and Guilt-Free: The Role of Self-Accountability in Influencing Preferences for Products with Ethical Attributes.|journal=Journal of Marketing|volume=77|pages=104–119|doi=10.1509/jm.11.0454|pmid=}}</ref>
According to the [[self-discrepancy theory]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Higgins|first=Tory|date=1987|title=Self-Discrepancy. A Theory Relating Self and Affect.|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/psychology/higgins/papers/HIGGINS=PSYCH%20REVIEW%201987.pdf|journal=American Psychological Association|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> there are a number of "selves" guiding and shaping one's behavior: * the actual self - the present self that one is. * the ideal self - the self toward which one strives and aspires to be. * the ought self - the self toward which a sense of duty or responsibility is perceived and felt. Guilt can be associated with failure to meet social expectations, thus self-standards can be heavily influenced by social norms which lead to the juxtaposition between one's own judgement of one's behavior and others' judgements of one's behavior. However, individuals are eventually motivated to meet self-standards regardless to others's judgement since social norms become easily internalized through socialization.<ref name=":2" />
The level of private self characterizing guilt leads to the definition of it as the negative emotional state associated with possible objection to one's actions, inaction, circumstances or intentions.
Consumers are therefore torn between the awareness of their potentially negative impact, and their willingness to enjoying the whole process of consumption. GFC can be understood as a minimization of the feeling of guilt without necessarily aiming at zero impact condition.<ref name=":0"/>
This unachievable freedom from negative emotional states, can be seen in the light of the psychological nature of human beings as characterized by a very heterogeneous mix of status, among which the genuine pleasure derived from consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globescan.com/98-press-releases-2013/291-two-and-a-half-billion-aspirational-consumers-mark-shift-in-sustainable-consumption.html|title=From Obligation To Desire: 2.5 Billion Aspiration Consumers Mark Shift in Sustainable Consumption.|last=|first=|date=October 2013|website=Globescan|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The fact that consumers feel the need to satisfy this sort of hedonism, makes it impossible for them to completely stop their damaging consumption patterns; as a consequences companies want to actively reduce the dichotomy by acting as mediator between the various selves.
== Guilt and buyer's remorse == GFC can be seen as a way to prevent [[buyer's remorse]], although the latter is a post-purchase dissonance mainly associated with monetary concerns.
The distinction between the two phenomena comes from the fact that buyer's remorse involves the negative feelings emerging after an excessively expensive product or service, while GFC embraces three different areas of concern. Moreover, buyer's remorse arises after the purchase is accomplished and companies can actively try to alleviate it through money back guarantees,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=Darren W.|date=October 2003|title=The Nature of Self-Reported Guilt in Consumption Contexts|jstor=40216496|journal=Marketing Letters 14|volume=14|issue=3|pages=159–171|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> while the sense of guiltiness involving GFC is minimized at the root when firms engage themselves in more responsible production and distribution processes.
== GFC in luxury goods == GFC has been influencing luxury market since even wealthiest consumers are becoming suspicious with regard to brands promoting fancy lifestyle.
Wealthy consumers indeed seem more and more influenced by the so-called "existential guilt", a particular sense of guilt individuals may even experience if they feel they benefit from unjustified privileges relative to others or if they accept some responsibility for social ills.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Shame and guilt in interpersonal relationships.|last=Tangney|first=June Price|publisher=Guilford Press|year=1995|isbn=|location=New York|pages=114–139}}</ref>
As a consequence, affluent consumers are putting global and social considerations as their first priority, strengthening the shift from conspicuous consumption to more conscientious buying habits.<ref name=":3" />
One popular way in which luxury brands are approaching and exploiting guilt-free consumption, is the attenuation of consumers' sense of guilt, hopefully followed by some sort of "license to indulge" in the desired product or service, through the promotion of charity organizations partnerships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2015-12-luxury-charity-partnerships-retail-sales-holiday.html|title=Luxury-charity partnerships can help promote retail sales this holiday season|last=|first=|date=14 December 2015|website=phys.org|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Companies' involvement == GFC's trend affected the way in which companies engage themselves in the creation of value through products, services, production processes and social initiatives. This tendency, aimed at supporting a more conscious and guiltless pattern of consumption, begun even before GFC's full development.
[[The Body Shop]] anticipated the trend by joining environmental and human rights campaigns, for example inviting people to wash up empty bottles of products and having them refilled at the shop. Other examples of the British firm's involvement in social causes are its minimal packaging policy and the project aimed at helping disadvantages communities through Community Trade program.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Promotional reflexivity: irony, de-fethisation and moralziation in the bodyshop promotional rhetoric.|last=Sassatelli|first=Roberta|publisher=I libri di Emil|year=2010|isbn=978-88-96026-29-8|location=Bologna|pages=229–247}}</ref>
In more recent times, there has been fuller engagement of firms in helping consumers minimizing their sense of guilt. In some cases companies focused on absolving one of the three areas of concern related to guilt-free consumption, but it is not always clear to which areas a particular strategy can be linked to since the three dimensions are often overlapping. * Guilt free consumption implementation in the first area of concern. The strategy implemented by [[McDonald's]] and [[Burger King]] can be understood in the light of the first class of GFC areas of concern: the personal self. In 2013 Burger King launched Satisfires, a line of fries with 40% of fat and 30% of calories less than McDonald's equivalent. Meanwhile, McDonald's announced a global partnership with the Alliance for a Healthier Generation in order to provide consumers with healthier meals: side-salad, fruit or vegetables as substitute for fried. Furthermore, the company decided that at least 70% of the food prepared and sold by a specific store of McDonald's, had to come from that same country in which the store was located.<ref name=":0" /> * Guilt-free consumption's implementation in the second area of concern. In the Netherlands, a new generation of mobile phones, by the local firm [[Fairphone]], provided smartphones which are manufactured without using minerals and with a special care of workers' welfare. This type of strategy fits the second area of concern related to GFC, therefore involving society and nature.<ref name=":0" /> * Guilt-free consumption's implementation in the third area of concern. Miya's Sushi, a sushi restaurant chain in Connecticut, went beyond simply avoiding offering endangered fish species in its menu, it provided delicacies made with invasive species that were damaging the local habitat.<ref name=":0" />
These two cases can be linked to the third dimension of GFC regarding the planet.<ref name=":0" />
== See also == * [[Cause marketing]] * [[Consumer behaviour]] * [[Critical consumerism]] * [[Eco-gastronomy]] * [[Green brands]] * [[Organic food culture]]
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Guilt-free consumption}} [[Category:Consumption]] [[Category:Guilt]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|UK|naval}} |Ship name=HMS ''C33'' |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Chatham Dockyard|HM Dockyard Chatham]] |Ship laid down=29 March 1909 |Ship launched=10 May 1910 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=13 August 1910 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship renamed= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship homeport= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Sunk by mine, 4 August 1915 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[British C-class submarine|C-class submarine]] |Ship displacement=*{{convert|290|LT|t|abbr=on}} surfaced *{{convert|320|LT|t|abbr=on}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|142|ft|3|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|13|ft|7|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|11|ft|6|in|1|abbr=on}} |Ship power=*{{convert|600|bhp|kW|lk=in|abbr=on}} [[petrol]] *{{convert|300|hp|kW|abbr=on}} electric |Ship propulsion=*1 × 16-cylinder Vickers petrol engine *1 × [[electric motor]] |Ship speed=*{{convert|13|kn|abbr=on|lk=in}} surfaced *{{convert|8|kn|abbr=on}} submerged |Ship range={{convert|910|nmi|abbr=on|lk=in}} at {{convert|12|kn|abbr=on}} on the surface |Ship test depth={{convert|100|ft|1}} |Ship complement=2 officers and 14 ratings |Ship armament=2 × [[British 18 inch torpedo|18 in (450 mm)]] bow [[torpedo tube]]s |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''C33''''' was one of 38 [[British C-class submarine|C-class submarine]]s built for the [[Royal Navy]] in the first decade of the 20th century. The boat survived the First World War and was sold for [[ship breaking|scrap]] in 1920.
==Design and description== The C-class boats of the 1907–08 and subsequent Naval Programmes were modified to improve their speed, both above and below the surface. The submarine had a length of {{convert|142|ft|3|in|m|1}} [[length overall|overall]], a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|13|ft|7|in|m|1}} and a mean [[draft (ship)|draft]] of {{convert|11|ft|6|in|m|1}}. They [[displacement (ship)|displaced]] {{convert|290|LT|t}} on the surface and {{convert|320|LT|t}} submerged. The C-class submarines had a crew of two officers and fourteen [[naval rating|ratings]].<ref name=gg9>Gardiner & Gray, p. 87</ref>
For surface running, the boats were powered by a single 12-cylinder<ref>Harrison, Chapter 25</ref> {{convert|600|bhp|lk=in|0|adj=on}} [[Vickers]] [[petrol engine]] that drove one [[propeller shaft]]. When submerged the propeller was driven by a {{convert|300|hp|0|adj=on}} [[electric motor]].<ref name=gg9/> They could reach {{convert|13|kn|lk=in}} on the surface and {{convert|8|kn}} underwater. On the surface, the C class had a range of {{convert|910|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|12|kn}}.<ref>Harrison, Chapters 3</ref>
The boats were armed with two [[British 18 inch torpedo|18-inch (45 cm)]] [[torpedo tube]]s in the bow. They could carry a pair of reload torpedoes, but generally did not as they would have to remove an equal weight of fuel in compensation.<ref>Harrison, Chapter 27</ref>
==Construction and career== HMS ''C33'' was built by [[Chatham Dockyard|HM Dockyard Chatham]]. She was laid down on 29 March 1909 and was commissioned on 13 August 1910. ''C33'' was involved in the [[U-Boat]] trap tactic. The tactic was to use a decoy trawler to tow a submarine. When a U-boat was sighted, the tow line and communication line was slipped and the submarine would attack the U-boat. The tactic was partly successful, but it was abandoned after the loss of two C class submarines. In both cases, all the crew were lost.
''C33'' was one of the two C class submarines lost while employing this tactic. She was [[Naval mine|mine]]d off [[Great Yarmouth]] while operating with the armed trawler ''Malta'' on 4 August 1915.

N.|date=January 1979|publisher=Submariners Association: Barrow in Furness Branch|accessdate=19 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519040644/http://www.rnsubs.co.uk/Boats/BR3043/chapter07.php|archivedate=19 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=December 2017}} {{other uses|Hadlow (disambiguation)}} {|{{Infobox ship begin |infobox caption=}} <!-- age of sail --><!-- caption: yes, nodab, or <caption text> --> {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|United Kingdom|civil}} |Ship name= ''Hadlow'' |Ship owner= W. Parker & Co |Ship namesake= |Ship builder=J. Munn, St. Rocques, Quebec{{sfn|Hackman|2001|p=281}} |Ship original cost= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1814, Quebec |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship registry= London |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= Foundered 1823 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= [[Snow (ship)|Snow]] |Ship tons burthen=372,{{sfn|Bateson|1959|p=292-93}} 372{{small|{{frac|32|94}}}},{{sfn|Hackman|2001|p=281}} 374,<ref name=LR1818>[https://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015005686806?urlappend=%3Bseq=252 ''[[Lloyd's Register]]'' (1818), Seq.№9.]</ref> or 376<ref name=RS1824/> ([[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]]) |Ship length= |Ship beam= |Ship draught= |Ship decks= Two decks |Ship hold depth= |Ship propulsion= Sails |Ship sail plan= [[Full-rigged ship]] |Ship complement= |Ship armament= |Ship notes= }} |}
'''''Hadlow''''' was a 374-ton merchant sailing ship built in 1814 at [[Quebec City|Quebec]], [[British North America]]. She made two voyages [[convicts in Australia|transporting convicts]] from England and Ireland to Australia. She plied between England, India and Sierra Leone before being lost with all hands in 1823.
==Construction== ''Hadlow'' was built for W. Parker & Co.; she was a two-deck [[full-rigged ship]] with a [[Copper sheathing|coppered]] hull, she was assessed at around 374 tons (bm). Her port of registry was London.<ref name=LR1821>{{cite journal |url=https://archive.org/stream/lloydsregisters89unkngoog#page/n239/mode/2up |journal=Lloyd's Register |title=The Register of Shipping for the Year 1821. |year=1821 |page=240}}</ref><ref name=Hadlow18/>
==History== Few details of her first years of service are known. Having left London under the command of one Captain Davison on 27 May 1815,<ref name=Houston>{{cite book|last1=Houston|first1=Stuart|last2=Ball|first2=Tim|last3=Huston|first3=Mary|title=Eighteenth-Century Naturalists of Hudson Bay|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|year=2003|isbn=9780773569751|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r2GFiCObVH4C&pg=PA152&dq=%22Hadlow%22+ship&hl=de&sa=X&ei=dviUUqLwGoOWyQPmwYG4Bg&ved=0CHQQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=%22Hadlow%22%20ship&f=false}}</ref> ''Hadlow'' sailed from [[Cromarty]], Scotland, to the [[Hudson Bay]] in June with 34 colonists from [[Stromness]] and possibly [[Loch Eriboll]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Robertson's Landmarks of Toronto: A Collection of Historical Sketches of the Old Town of York from 1792 Until 1837, and of Toronto from 1834 to 1914 |editor=John Ross Robertson |year=1914 |page=121 |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=d-aUUp7zHqaeyQOXmoCADw&hl=de&id=EfmUEU9El3wC&dq=Hadlow+1815+Scotland&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Hadlow}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Silver Chief: Lord Selkirk and the Scottish Pioneers of Belfast, Baldoon and Red River |author=Lucille H. Campey |publisher=Dundum |year=2003 |isbn=9781554883547 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hB4boyzSXQkC&pg=PT182&dq=Hadlow+1815+Scotland&hl=de&sa=X&ei=d-aUUp7zHqaeyQOXmoCADw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Hadlow&f=false}}</ref> She arrived in [[York Factory]] on 26 August 1815 and left again on 7 September to winter at [[Strutton Islands|Strutton Sound]]. ''Hadlow'' arrived back in London on 4 November the following year.<ref name=Houston/>
Described as "new built", ''Hadlow'' sailed from London for [[Bengal]], [[Company rule in India|India]] via [[Madeira]], Portugal in February 1817 under the command of Captain Edward Lamb.<ref name=MC150117>{{Cite news |title=(advertisement) |newspaper=The Morning Chronicle |date=15 January 1817 |issue=14885 }}</ref> During the return voyage from [[Calcutta]], Captain Lamb died on 31 December 1817.<ref name=MC230418>{{Cite news |title=DIED. |newspaper=The Morning Chronicle |date=23 April 1818 |issue=15281 }}</ref> Command of the ship was taken by Captain Anderson. ''Hadlow'' collided with the [[transport ship]] ''Wyton'' in the [[English Channel]] in April 1818.<ref name=CM070518>{{Cite news |title=LLOYD'S MARINE LIST - May 1. |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=7 May 1818 |issue=15079 }}</ref>
''Hadlow'' appears in ''[[Lloyd's Register]]'' for 1818 with master Lamb, changing to J. Craigie, and trade London—India, changing to London—Botany Bay.<ref name=LR1818/>
In July 1818, ''Hadlow'' was fitted for the [[convicts in Australia|transportation of convicts]] at [[Deptford Dockyard]], [[Kent]]. Her guard of a lieutenant and 32 troops of the [[48th (Northamptonshire) Regiment of Foot|48th Regiment of Foot]] embarked on 17 July, along with six women and four children. She sailed to [[Woolwich]], Kent on 30 July and took 50 male convicts from the [[prison hulk]] [[HMS Zeeland (1796)|''Justitia'']] on 1 August. The next day, she sailed for [[Sheerness]], Kent where she took 97 convicts from the prison hulks {{HMS|Bellerophon|1786|2}} and [[HMS Edgar (1779)|''Retribution'']].
''Hadlow'' departed from Sheerness for [[New South Wales]] on 22 August under the command of Captain John Craigie.<ref group=Note>Captain Craigie's surname also appears as "Craige" and "Cragie" in sources. The spelling "Craigie" has been adopted for this article.</ref><ref name=MP250818>{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Morning Post |date=25 August 1818 |issue=14851 }}</ref> Having called in at the [[Cape of Good Hope]] ''en route'',<ref name=Hadlow18>{{cite web |url=http://www.jenwilletts.com/convict_ship_hadlow_1818.htm |title=Convict Ship Hadlow 1818 |publisher=Jen Willetts |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> she arrived at [[Port Jackson]] on 23 December,<ref name=SG2612187>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2178440 |title=Ship News. |newspaper=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser |location=NSW |date=26 December 1818 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref name=HTG020119>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article655323 |title=HOBART TOWN. |newspaper=The Hobart Town Gazette and Southern Reporter |location=Tasmania |date=2 January 1819 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and her cargo of 149 male convicts were turned over to the authorities there, one having died ''en route''.{{refn|The figures don't tally, but are given per sources quoted. Bateson too gives the number of convicts embarked as 150, with one dying ''en route''.|group=Note}}<ref name=SG020119>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2178460 |title=Sydney. |newspaper=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser |location=NSW |date=2 January 1819 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>{{sfn|Bateson|1959|p=328}} A woman who had been taken on board at the Cape of Good Hope gave birth to a stillborn child shortly after arrival at Port Jackson and subsequently died. The convicts were disembarked on 4 January 1819 for inspection by [[Governor Macquarie]].<ref name=Hadlow18/>
''Hadlow'' departed from Sydney, New South Wales for [[Calcutta]], India on or about 20 January 1819.<ref name=SG090119>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2178468 |title=Classified Advertising. |newspaper=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser |location=NSW |date=9 January 1819 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> She departed from Calcutta in late May 1819 for London, where she arrived in early December.<ref name=CM021219>{{Cite news |title=(untitled) |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=2 December 1819 |issue=15328 }}</ref>
''Hadlow'' departed from Deptford on 20 February 1820 for Gravesend, where, on 23 February, she embarked a captain, sergeant and 32 privates of the 48th Regiment. She then sailed to [[Cobh]], [[County Cork]], to collect 150 male convicts, who were embarked on 23 March. ''Hadlow'' sailed on 2 April and arrived at Port Jackson on 5 August 1820.{{sfn|Bateson|1959|p=292-93}}<ref name=Hadlow20>{{cite web |url=http://www.jenwilletts.com/convict_ship_hadlow_1820.htm |title=Convict Ship Hadlow 1820 |publisher=Jen Willetts |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> Two of her 150 convicts died ''en route''.<ref name=SG050820>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2179645 |title=Ship News. |newspaper=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser |location=NSW |date=5 August 1820 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>{{sfn|Bateson|1959|p=328}} The convicts were disembarked on 15 August.<ref name=Hadlow20/> ''Hadlow'' departed from Sydney on 15 September for [[Jakarta|Batavia]], [[Netherlands East Indies]].<ref name=SG160920>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2179745 |title=Ship News. |newspaper=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser |location=NSW |date=16 September 1820 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> She returned from Batavia in October 1820 in company with ''Earl St. Vincent'', ''Mangles'' and ''Neptune''; between them the four ships had brought 603 convicts to Port Jackson.<ref name=HTG071020>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article658511 |title=(untitled) |newspaper=The Hobart Town Gazette and Southern Reporter |location=Tasmania |date=7 October 1820 |accessdate=29 December 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
''Hadlow'' sailed from London for [[Bombay]], India on or about 10 October 1821.<ref name=Times200921>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=(advertisement) |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=20 September 1821 |page_number=1 |issue=11356 |column=A }}</ref> She arrived in April 1822.<ref name=MP210322>{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Morning Post |date=21 March 1822 |issue=16075 }}</ref> ''Hadlow'' departed from Bombay on 2 June 1822 and arrived in [[The Downs (ship anchorage)|The Downs]] in mid-October.<ref name=MP141022>{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Morning Post |date=14 October 1822 |issue=16093 }}</ref>
In 1823 she underwent a small repair. The ''Register of Shipping'' (1824), gave her master's name as Pounder, and her trade as London—Sierra Leone.<ref name=RS1824>[https://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015006563160?urlappend=%3Bseq=259 ''Register of Shipping''] (1824), Seq.№14.</ref> While she was at Sierra Leone, [[yellow fever]] broke out on ''Hadlow'', killing four of her crew. The disease was brought to Sierra Leone either by the merchant ship ''Caroline'' or by {{USS|Cyane|1815|6}}.<ref name=DM160723>{{Cite news |title=SATURDAY, SUNDAY and TUESDAY's POSTS |newspaper=Derby Mercury |date=16 July 1823 |issue=4749 }}</ref> At the time, ''Hadlow'' was under the command of Captain Praguel, or Prangnell.<ref name=MP080923>{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=The Morning Post |date=8 September 1823 |issue=16447 }}</ref>
==Fate== ''Hadlow'' departed for London on 31 August, but subsequently foundered with the loss of all hands.<ref name=CM220324>{{Cite news |title=Ship News |newspaper=Caledonian Mercury |date=22 March 1824 |issue=16007 }}</ref> There was a report of her arriving in The Downs on 4 September 1823,<ref name=MP080923/> but this is clearly an error.
==Notes, citations and references== '''Notes''' {{reflist|group=Note}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} '''References''' *{{cite book |title =The Convict Ships, 1787-1868| first =Charles | last =Bateson | year =1959 | publisher =Brown, Son & Ferguson | oclc =3778075 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Hackman |first=Rowan |year=2001 |title=Ships of the East India Company |location=Gravesend, Kent |publisher=World Ship Society |ISBN=0-905617-96-7 |ref=harv}}
[[Category:1814 ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Quebec]] [[Category:Merchant ships of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Convict ships to New South Wales]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1818]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1823]] [[Category:Full-rigged ships]] [[Category:Passenger ships of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:English colonization of the Americas]] [[Category:Ships lost with all hands]]

company now defunct
revision.text:
[[File:Helioculture image.png|thumb|right|300px|Helioculture combines brackish water (or graywater), nutrients, photosynthetic organisms, carbon dioxide, and sunlight to create fuel.]]
'''Joule Unlimited''', formerly known as Joule Biotechnologies,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/business/technology/articles/2010/04/28/cambridge_firm_set_to_plow_30m_into_nonfossil_fuel_production/ | work=The Boston Globe | first=Erin | last=Ailworth | title=$30M Is Feeding A Quest For Nonfossil Fuels | date=April 28, 2010}}</ref> was a producer of alternative energy technologies based in [[Bedford, Massachusetts]]. The company developed a process to generate hydrocarbon-based fuel by combining non-fresh water, nutrients, [[cyanobacteria]], [[carbon dioxide]], and sunlight. After ten years of operation and building a demonstration plant in New Mexico, the company shut down in August 2017. The company shut down after management was unable to raise money, which the CEO attributed to [[Hillary Clinton]] losing the 2016 Presidential election. <ref>[http://dailycaller.com/2017/10/22/exclusive-podestas-green-company-forced-to-close-because-hillary-lost-the-election/]</ref>
==Technology claims==
The company claimed it would be able to produce more than 20,000 gallons of fuel per acre per year (19,000 m<sup>3</sup>/km<sup>2</sup>·a).<ref name=wsj11>{{cite news|last=TOTTY|first=MICHAEL|title=A Faster Path to Biofuels|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204524604576610703305792650?mod=WSJ_WSJ_News_JOURNALREPORTS7_2|accessdate=11 December 2011|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=October 17, 2011}}</ref>
Helioculture uses photosynthetic organisms, but is otherwise distinct from the process that makes [[Algae fuel|fuel from algae]]. Oils made from algae usually have to be refined into fuel following a batch process, but helioculture produces fuel directly - either ethanol or hydrocarbons - that do not need refining. The Helioculture process also does not produce biomass. This process is enabled by the discovery of unique genes coding for enzymatic mechanisms that enable the direct synthesis of both alkane, olefin, ethanol, and other key molecules.<ref>[http://biofuelsdigest.com/bdigest/2010/06/03/portrait-of-a-transformative-technology-joule-unlimited/ Portrait of a Transformative Technology: Joule Unlimited] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810211453/http://biofuelsdigest.com/bdigest/2010/06/03/portrait-of-a-transformative-technology-joule-unlimited/ |date=2010-08-10 }}, Biofuels Digest, June 3, 2010</ref> Helioculture allows for [[brackish water]] or [[graywater]], nonindustrial waste water from sources such as baths and washing machines,<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-GreenBusiness/idUSTRE56Q5P520090727 U.S. company hopes to make fuel from sunlight, CO2], Reuters, July 27, 2009</ref> to be used, while traditional biofuels such as cellulosic ethanol require fresh water.
Joule Unlimited claimed that its product would have been cost competitive with crude oil at $50 a barrel ($310/m<sup>3</sup>). The company also stated that its product could supply all of the transportation fuel for the United States from an area the size of the [[Texas panhandle]].<ref>[http://www.technologyreview.com/business/23073/ A Biofuel Process to Replace All Fossil Fuels], technologyreview.com, July 27, 2009</ref>
Joule Unlimited did not reveal the name of the organism that it used, although it acknowledged that the company had modified the organism.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/business/technology/articles/2009/07/27/carbon_dioxide_sun_and_secret_ingredient_are_firms_fuel_recipe/ Carbon dioxide, sun, and secret ingredient are firm’s fuel recipe], Boston Globe, July 27, 2009</ref> In September, 2010, Joule received a patent for genetically altered bacterium.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/14/science/earth/14fuel.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=joule%20unlimited&st=cse Biotech Company to Patent Fuel-Secreting Bacterium], New York Times, September 13, 2010</ref>
==People== Joule Unlimited was founded in 2007 within Flagship VentureLabs by Noubar Afeyan and [[David Berry (inventor)|David Berry]]. In addition to its founders, Joule's Board of Directors included [[Graham Allison]], [[Anatoly Chubais]], Stelios Papadopoulos, Caroline Dorsa, and [[Ruben Vardanian]].<ref>[http://www.jouleunlimited.com/board-directors-0]</ref> Joule's Scientific Advisory Board includes synthetic biologists [[George M. Church]] and [[James Collins (bioengineer)|Jim Collins]].
==Audi partnership== After building a demonstration plant in New Mexico, Joule Unlimited entered into a strategic partnership with [[Audi]] in 2012 to accelerate the commercialization of their fuels, ethanol named Sunflow-E and diesel named Sunflow-D.<ref>{{cite news|title=Joule and Audi partner on sustainable liquid transportation fuels|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/09/joule-audi-20120917.html|accessdate=7 May 2015|work=Green Car Congress|date=17 September 2012}}</ref> Audi brands them as e-ethanol and [[e-diesel]] respectively.<ref>{{cite web|title=Audi e-diesel and e-ethanol|url=http://www.audi-technology-portal.de/en/mobility-for-the-future/audi-future-lab-mobility_en/audi-future-energies_en/audi-e-diesel-and-e-ethanol|publisher=Audi|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links==
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20110208173015/http://www.jouleunlimited.com/ Official Web page of Joule Biotechnologies] *[https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2009/07/27/joule-biotechnologies-unveils-liquid-fuel-from-solar-power/?mod=rss_WSJBlog Joule Biotechnologies Unveils Liquid Fuel From Solar Power], Wall St. Journal, July 27, 2009 *[http://www.scientificamerican.com/blog/60-second-science/post.cfm?id=joule-biotechnologies-announce-new-2009-07-27 Joule Biotechnologies announce new biofuel jargon, scant details], Scientific American, July 27, 2009 *[https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/27/joule-biofuel-berry-technology-breakthroughs-joule.html A Cagey Bet On Clean Tech], Forbes, July 27, 2009 *Patents assigned to Joule Unlimited ** <small>[http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=US_7785861 US 7785861] ("Hyperphotosynthetic organisms", 2010-08-31) ** [http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=US_7794969 US 7794969] ("Methods and compositions for the recombinant biosynthesis of n-alkanes", 2010-09-14)</small> *Patent applications (Joule Unlimited personnel) ** <small>[http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=WO_2010_062707_A1 WO 2010 062707 A1] ("Methods and compositions for producing carbon-based products of interest in micro-organisms", 2010-06-03) ** [http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=WO_2010_036951_A3R4 WO 2010 036951 A3R4] ("Methods and compositions for producing carbon-based products of interest in micro-organisms", 2010-06-24) ** [http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=WO_2010_068288_A3R4 WO 2010 068288 A3R4] ("Solar biofactory, photobioreactors, passive thermal regulation systems and methods for producing products", 2010-10-07) ** [http://www.patentlens.net/patentlens/patents.html?patnums=WO_2010_017245_A8R5 WO 2010 017245 A8R5] ("Methods and compositions for producing carbon-based products of interest in micro-organisms", 2010-10-14)</small> * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?Db=gene&Cmd=retrieve&dopt=full_report&list_uids=3775018 Synpcc7942_1594] — [[acyl-ACP reductase]] (''[[Synechococcus elongatus]]'' PCC 7942) ''(see US 7794969)'' * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20671186/ "Microbial biosynthesis of alkanes"], Schirmer A, Rude MA, Li X, Popova E, del Cardayre SB, ''Science'' 2010 Jul 30;329(5991):559-62.
[[Category:Alternative energy]] [[Category:Algae biomass producers]]

'''Julius Briganticus''' (died AD 69) was a [[Batavians|Batavian]] who commanded [[auxiliaries (Roman military)|auxiliary]] cavalry in the [[Roman Army]]. He was the son of the sister of [[Gaius Julius Civilis]], the leader of the [[Batavian rebellion]], who apparently hated his nephew. The ''nomen'' Julius indicates he was a [[Roman citizenship|Roman citizen]]. The ''cognomen'' Briganticus perhaps suggests he, or his father, gained distinction fighting against the [[Brigantes]] of northern [[Roman Britain|Britain]].
In 69, during the civil wars of the [[Year of Four Emperors]], Briganticus initially fought for [[Otho]] but surrendered to [[Vitellius]]'s forces after the battle of [[Piacenza|Placentia]].<ref>[[Tacitus]], ''[[Histories (Tacitus)|Histories]]'' [[Wikisource:The Histories (Tacitus)/Book 2#22|2.22]]</ref> He later commanded a picked squad of cavalry that had been formed by Vitellius but went over to [[Vespasian]].<ref>Tacitus, ''Histories'' [[Wikisource:The Histories (Tacitus)/Book 4#70|4.70]]</ref> He died fighting for the Romans under [[Quintus Petillius Cerialis]] against his uncle during the Batavian revolt.<ref>Tacitus, ''Histories'' [[Wikisource:The Histories (Tacitus)/Book 5#21|5.21]]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Julius Briganticus}} [[Category:Ancient Romans in Britain]] [[Category:Batavian people]] [[Category:People of the Year of the Four Emperors]] [[Category:Germanic warriors]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]] [[Category:69 deaths]] [[Category:1st-century Romans]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Place of birth unknown]] [[Category:Julii|Briganticus]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=June 2017}} '''Kochakkan Chacko Abraham''' was the [[Governor of Andhra Pradesh]] between 15 August 1978 – 15 August 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://governor.ap.nic.in/governor/exgovernors.html|title=Former governors of Andhra Pradesh|date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403223057/http://governor.ap.nic.in/governor/exgovernors.html|archivedate=3 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/01/03/stories/2011010359560200.htm|title=OMC alumni to fight against medical reimbursement|date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109015201/http://www.hindu.com/2011/01/03/stories/2011010359560200.htm|archivedate=9 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He belonged to [[Indian National Congress]].
==Early life== He was born in [[Cochin]], [[Kerala]] on 20 January 1899. He has a bachelor's degree and worked for 30 years as a [[teacher]], also as a [[headmaster]].
==Career== He was a Member of Travancore Cochin Legislative Assembly (1954–56). He was the 1st and 2nd KLA Legislator from Njarakkal-Congress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.niyamasabha.org/codes/members/m011.htm|title=K. C. Abraham|date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419192824/http://www.niyamasabha.org/codes/members/m011.htm|archivedate=19 April 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/no-end-to-problems-between-andhra-pradesh-cm-n.t.-rama-rao-and-state-governor/1/348382.html|title=Governor row|date=30 April 1986|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419192255/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/no-end-to-problems-between-andhra-pradesh-cm-n.t.-rama-rao-and-state-governor/1/348382.html|archivedate=19 April 2017}}</ref> He entered active politics quite late after he retired as a [[school]] headmaster. He was a member of the [[Congress Working Committee|Congress working committee]] (CWC) at the time of the great split in 1969. With the 21 member committee was split into 10 Pro- syndicate and 10 Pro- Indira group , it was KC Abraham who played a mediator role to bring the two groups together though he was very much pro- Syndicate. Finally he stood by his Pro- Syndicate conviction which resulted in the expulsion of [[Indira Gandhi|Indira Gandh]]<nowiki/>i from the [[Indian National Congress]].
==Personal life== He was married and has one son. He died on 14 March 1986.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abraham, K. C.}} [[Category:Governors of Andhra Pradesh]] [[Category:Indian National Congress politicians from Kerala]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Kochi]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Members of the Travancore-Cochin Legislative Assembly]] [[Category:20th-century Indian politicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{use Indian English|date=August 2016}} {{For|the 2011 film|Khap (film)}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=August 2010}} {{cleanup|date=April 2010}} }} A '''Khap''' is a community organisation representing a clan or a group of related clans. They are found mostly in northern India, particularly among the [[Jat people]] of [[Western Uttar Pradesh]] and [[Haryana]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.com/hindi/india/2009/08/090805_honourkill_expert_as.shtml क्या है खाप पंचायत, क्यों है उसका दबदबा?, Atul Sagar, BBC 5 August 2009]</ref> although historically the term has also been used among other communities. A '''Khap Panchayat''' is an assembly of Khap elders, and a '''Sarv Khap''' is an assembly of many Khap Panchayats like [[Dahiya Khap]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Haryanas-biggest-khap-panchayat-scripts-history-allows-inter-caste-marriages/articleshow/34016585.cms |title=Haryana’s biggest khap panchayat scripts history, allows inter-caste marriages |first=Manveer |last=Saini |date=21 April 2014 |work=The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.epw.in/system/files/pdf/1965_17/51/the_jats_of_northern_indiatheir_traditional_political_systemii.pdf |title=The Jats of Northern India Their Traditional Political System — II |first=M. C. |last=Pradhan |journal=Economic and Political Weekly |date=18 December 1965}}</ref>
Khaps are not affiliated with the formally elected government bodies and is instead concerned with the affairs of the Khap it represents.<ref>[http://www.samaylive.com/editorial/262627/khap-deleted-conditional-ban-on-interracial-marriages.html खाप पंचायतों का हृदय परिवर्तन! अंजलि सिन्हा, Sahara Samay, 26 Apr 2014]</ref> It is not affiliated with the democratically elected local assemblies that are also termed [[Panchayati raj (India)|Panchayat]]. A Khap Panchayat has no official government recognition or authority, but can exert significant social influence within the community it represents.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kaur |first=Ravinder |url=https://www.academia.edu/671328/Khap_panchayats_sex_ratio_and_female_agency |title=Khap panchayats, sex ratio and female agency | Ravinder Kaur |publisher=Academia.edu |date=2010-06-05 |accessdate=2013-03-31}}</ref> The [[Baliyan Khap]] as led by [[Mahendra Singh Tikait]] until 2011 is one that has gained particular media attention.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/muzaffarnagar-riots-a-jat-family-protected-70-muslims-in-fugna-village/1/309827.html |title=Muzaffarnagar riots: A Jat family protected 70 Muslims in Fugna village |work=India Today |date=14 September 2013}}</ref>
== History ==
The Khaps evolved as tribal and village administrations. One of the terms used to denote the [[republic]]{{clarify|reason=what republic? surely not the Republic of India?|date=August 2016}} was the ''Khap''. Others were [[Pal (government)|Pal]], [[Janapada]], and [[Ganasangha]]. The Khap consisted a unit of 84 villages. The individual villages were governed by an elected council, known as the ''[[Panchayat]]''. A unit of seven villages was called a ''Thamba'' and 12 Thambas formed the Khap unit of 84 villages, though Khaps of 12 and 24 villages existed. Their elected leaders would determine which units would be represented at the Khap level.{{cn|date=September 2016}} The ''Sarv Khap'' (or ''All Khap'') Panchayat (Council) represented all the Khaps. The individual Khaps would elect leaders who would send delegates to represent their Khaps at the Sarv Khap. It was a political organisation, composed of all the clans, communities, and castes in the region.{{cn|date=September 2016}}
These Khaps are found from Northwest India down to [[Maharastra]], [[Chennai]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[Malwa]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Sindh]], [[Multan]], [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], [[Haryana]], and [[Uttar Pradesh]].{{cn|date=September 2016}}
== Decisions on social issues ==
The Khap Panchayats frequently make pronouncements on social issues, such as abortion, alcohol abuse, dowry, and to promote education,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/thesundaystandard/Khap-Panchayats-Root-for-Educated-Leaders/2015/08/16/article2976237.ece | title=Khap Panchayats Root for Educated Leaders | first=Harpreet | last=Bajwa | newspaper=New Indian Express | date=16 August 2015}}</ref> specially among girls.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Haryana-khaps-launch-campaign-for-girls-education/articleshow/36459145.cms | title=Haryana khaps launch campaign for girls' education | first=Sukhbir | last=Siwach | date=13 June 2014}}</ref> In October 2012, one Khap Panchayat leader in Haryana blamed the eating of [[chow mein]], a non-traditional food, for the rise in [[rape in India]], while another suggested that the age of marriage should be dropped from 18 to 16 because being married would make young women less susceptible to rape.<ref>{{cite news |work=The Times of India |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Haryana-khap-blames-consumption-of-chowmein-for-rapes/articleshow/16829882.cms |title=Haryana khap blames consumption of chowmein for rapes |first=Manveer |last=Saini |date=16 October 2012 |accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=The Telegraph |location=Calcutta |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1121008/jsp/nation/story_16065635.jsp#.V9djldFVK1E |title=Khap duo: Marry at 16 to check rape |date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref>
The largest Khap in Haryana is the Satrol Khap, which allowed inter-caste marriage in 2014,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Haryanas-biggest-khap-panchayat-scripts-history-allows-inter-caste-marriages/articleshow/34016585.cms |title=Haryana's Biggest Khap Creates history |date=11 April 2014 |first=Manvir |last=Saini |work=The Times of India }}</ref> providing the marriage is not within the same [[gotra]], village, or neighbouring villages.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://img.zeenews.com/hindi/news/india/700-yr-old-khap-ban-on-inter-caste-marriages-off/207500 | title=खाप पंचायत का ऐतिहासिक फैसला, अंतर्जातीय शादी को दी हरी झंडी | publisher=Zee News | date=21 April 2014}}</ref>
A 2015 Sarv Khap meeting launched a "Save daughters, educate daughter" movement.<ref>[http://dainiktribuneonline.com/2015/05/%E0%A4%AC%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%9F%E0%A5%80-%E0%A4%AC%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%93-%E0%A4%AC%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%9F%E0%A5%80-%E0%A4%AA%E0%A4%A2%E0%A4%BC%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%93-%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%81%E0%A4%A6%E0%A5%8D/ बेटी बचाओ, बेटी पढ़ाओ मुद्दे पर सर्वखाप महापंचायत, May - 17 - 2015 ]</ref>
The decisions of the patriarchal Khap Panchayats have often been associated with the practice of [[honour killing]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Marital Separation and Lethal Domestic Violence |first1=Desmond |last1=Ellis |first2=Noreen |last2=Stuckless |first3=Carrie |last3=Smith |publisher=Routledge |year=2015 |isbn=978-1-31752-213-3 |page=77 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=swrwBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA77}}</ref>
== Criticism == In recent times, the Khap system has attracted criticism from groups, citing the stark prejudice that such groups allegedly hold against others. The [[All India Democratic Women's Association]] has reported cases where the Khaps are alleged to have initiated threats of murder and violence to couples who marry outside of the circle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2125/stories/20041217002304200.htm |title=Caste terror |author=T.K. Rajalakshmi |work=frontline |volume=21 |issue=25 |date=4–17 December 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Opinion/Sunday_Specials/Panchayats_turn_into_kangaroo_courts/rssarticleshow/2351247.cms |title=Panchayats turn into kangaroo courts |date=9 September 2007 |author=Rohit Mullick & Neelam Raaj |work=The Times of India }}</ref>
The [[Supreme Court of India]] has declared Khap Panchayats to be illegal because they often decree or encourage honour killings or other institutionalised atrocities against boys and girls of different castes and religions who wish to get married or have married.<ref name="Venkatesan">{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article1710337.ece |location=Chennai, India |work=The Hindu |first=J. |last=Venkatesan |title=Stamp out khap panchayats: court |date=20 April 2011}}</ref>
{{blockquote|This is wholly illegal and has to be ruthlessly stamped out. There is nothing honourable in honour killing or other atrocities and, in fact, it is nothing but barbaric and shameful murder. Other atrocities in respect of the personal lives of people committed by brutal, feudal-minded persons deserve harsh punishment. Only this way can we stamp out such acts of barbarism and feudal mentality. Moreover, these acts take the law into their own hands, and amount to kangaroo courts, which are wholly illegal.<ref name="Venkatesan" />}}
In a 2012 report to the Supreme Court, Raju Ramachandaran, a Senior Advocate appointed by the Court to assist it in [[public interest litigation]] actions against Khap Panchayats, called for the arrest of "self styled" decision makers and for proactive action by the police to protect the fundamental rights of the people. He also asked for the recommendations to be converted into directions applicable to all [[states and union territories of India]] until a law is enacted by the [[Parliament of India|national parliament]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Rein-in-khaps-prevent-honour-killings-SC-panel/Article1-890134.aspx |title= Rein in khaps, prevent honour killings: SC panel |date= 17 July 2012}}</ref>
== Unofficial caste == There are sources that describe the Khap as unofficial caste system where the panchayat dominates all other members of the group.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=India Diversity|last=David|first=Hilda|last2=Jarman|first2=Francis|publisher=Om Books International|year=2017|isbn=9789386316974|location=|pages=1959}}</ref> Like the function of traditional caste and family systems, this Indian traditional institution engages in dispute resolution and the regulation of members' behavior.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Challenging The Rules(s) of Law: Colonialism, Criminology and Human Rights in India|last=Kannabiran|first=Kalpana|last2=Singh|first2=Ranbir|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2008|isbn=9780761936657|location=Los Angeles, CA|pages=331}}</ref> The group uses violence to maintain a rigid structure that controls members particularly, women, [[Dalit|Dalits]], [[Muslim|Muslims]], and youths. The panchayats aggressively push tradition and outlook in which caste divisions are desirable while violence towards lower castes is normal and acceptable.<ref name=":0" /> An important Khap ethos involves the commitment - for the good of the community - to work with one's body, heart and soul under the leadership of its leaders, who are believed to have high moral superiority.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Readings in Indian Sociology: Volume IX: Culture and Society|last=Visvanathan|first=Susan|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2013|isbn=9788132113904|location=Los Angeles, CA|pages=170}}</ref> For this reason, these leaders are afforded the right to demand a member's life.
Despite the criticisms against this institution, it remains popular in some parts of India because, in its benign form, it resolves disputes and achieves social order with less time and resources. Sometimes, the Indian government avoids a direct confrontation with the panchayat especially in rural areas.<ref name=":1" />
== See also ==
* [[Dahiya Khap]] * [[Khap (film)]] * [[Misl]] * [[Jat Mahasabha]] * [[Exogamy]] * [[Guddu Rangeela]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *{{cite book |chapter=Khap Panchayats in Haryana: Sites of Legal Pluralism |first=K. S. |last=Sangwan |title=Challenging The Rules(s) of Law: Colonialism, Criminology and Human Rights in India |editor1-first=Kalpana |editor1-last=Kannabiran |editor2-first=Ranbir |editor2-last=Singh |publisher=SAGE Publications |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-76193-665-7 |pages=331-354 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=EaMGo6zqzNYC&pg=PA331}}

{{for|the album by Dvorska Luda|Krvna osveta (album)}} {{redirect|Zakletva|the album by Stoja|Zakletva (album)}} '''Krvna Osveta''' ({{lang-sr|Крвна освета}}, '''''[[Blood feud]]''''') is a [[law]] of [[Feud|vendetta]] in [[Montenegro]] and [[Herzegovina]], practised by [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrins]], [[Serbs]], [[Bosniaks]] and [[Albanians of Montenegro|Albanian families]] throughout history since medieval times. It is an oath of revenge for vendetta, meaning that the person must take revenge on whomever killed his relative by killing the murderer or one of the murderer's close relatives.<ref>Zora Latinovic, ''Krvna Osveta'', 2005</ref>
The practice started in [[the Balkans]] in the 15th century, under [[Ottoman Empire|Turkish]] rule and the law decreased in the 19th century, when the Balkan countries slowly got their independence from the Ottoman Empire.<ref name="glas-javnosti">{{cite web|url=http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2005/07/29/srpski/F05072802.shtml |title=glas-javnosti |publisher=arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> In pre-Ottoman [[Serbian lands|Serbian principalities]], [[blood money (term)|blood money]] (''Vražda'') was paid, one half went to the Serbian Orthodox Church, while the other to the victim's family. Stefan Uroš (1240–1272) talks about the Vražda in his works. After Ottoman conquest of [[Serbia]], self-governing clans often feuded with each other. Families in Serbia abandoned the tradition as the bigger threats to family integrity was ethnic Albanians and Turks rather than of their own ethnic group.
When a family member has been killed, the perpetrator's family<sup>(Bratstva)</sup> has a "Blood debt" (''krvni dug'') which can only be removed when the victim's family (an appointed member, ''osvetnik'') has had their revenge by killing the aggressor or any member of the murderer's family (Often a close male kinsman, preferably the brother, killing of children was not encouraged). Only then has the family of the victim received peace (However, the blood feud continues if a relative decides to revenge, disregardless of who started).<ref name="BF" /> However, killing in your own house is the worst action, representing unmorality, which is a great shame in Montenegrin and Albanian cultures. If a criminal was murdered, it often did not result in a feud as criminality was negative in the eyes of society, but in some cases the criminal's family went on to kill serdars and other high ranked people.
*In Montenegro, the feuds were predominantly among [[Montenegrins]] and [[Albanians of Montenegro|ethnic Albanians]] themselves. *In Herzegovina (currently a region of both Montenegro and [[Bosnia & Herzegovina]]) [[Montenegrins]] had feuds with each other. A neutral region was Grahovo and Vučja Zuba (triangle of [[Boka Kotorska]], [[Montenegro]] and Herzegovina) where blood feuds were not recorded. *In [[Old Serbia]] ([[Kosovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]) If a Serb had a weak family, he could be protected by an Albanian bratstva from other [[Albanians]] in exchange for anything from [[weapons]] or [[folk attire]] [[textile|material]] (Serbs had rich textile art in the southern Serbian regions)
The Osveta is not limited to males, females that have their husbands or relatives killed could take on the ''blood debt'', an instance is recorded from the [[Bjelopavlići (clan)|Bjelopavlići clan]], where a widow took out revenge for the murder of her husband.<ref name="BF">{{Google books |id=oq4B2WGT9mYC |title=Blood Revenge: The Enactment and Management of Conflict in Montenegro and Other Tribal Societies }}</ref>
If a bratstva finds and captures a thief or murderer (in connection to the bratstva) they could go to the person's house or relatives and tell them that their relative is a murderer or thief and end with something like "If we kill him, we are not to be held for" If the relatives answers "Do what you like with him" -the bratstva, if they kill the captive, they don't have a blood debt to his relatives because they settled his fate.
The blood feuds resulted in major instability in Montenegro, Kosovo and diaspora of Montenegrins in later centuries. In [[Kosovo]], most cases of blood feuds were reconciled in the early 1990s in the course of a large-scale reconciliation movement to end blood feuds led by [[Anton Çetta]].<ref name="BJC2017">{{cite web |url= http://academic.oup.com/bjc/advance-article-abstract/doi/10.1093/bjc/azx002/2990197 |title=Did Nonviolent Resistance Fail in Kosovo? |last1=Marsavelski |first1=Aleksandar |last2=Sheremeti |first2=Furtuna |last3=Braithwaite |first3=John |website=British Journal of Criminology |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> The largest reconciliation gathering took place at Verrat e Llukës on 1 May 1990, which had between 100,000 and 500,000 participants. By 1992 the reconciliation campaign ended at least 1,200 deadly blood feuds, and in 1993 not a single homicide occurred in Kosovo.<ref name="BJC2017" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
== See also == * [[Gjakmarrja]] or ''"Besa"'', the Albanian law of vendetta.

revision.text:
{{pp-semi|small=yes}} {{About|the induction of specific modes or states of consciousness}} {{multiple image | align = right | total_width = 450 | image1 = Sivakempfort.jpg | alt1=Shiva | image2 = Monkey gives honey to Buddha Shakyamuni, India, Bihar, probably Kurkihar, Pala dynasty, c. 1000 AD, black stone - Östasiatiska museet, Stockholm - DSC09270.JPG | alt2=Buddha | image3 = Mahavir.jpg | alt3=Mahavir | footer = Statue of [[Shiva]] (''left''), [[Gautama Buddha]] (''center'') and [[Mahavira]] (''right'') performing yogic meditation in the [[Lotus position|Lotus position or Padmasana]] posture }} {{multiple image | align = right | total_width = 300 | image1=Swami Vivekananda 1896.jpg | alt1=Swami Vivekananda | image2=Hsuan Hua Hong Kong 1.jpeg | alt2=Hsuan Hua | footer = [[Hindu]] monk [[Swami Vivekananda]] (''left'') and [[Buddhist]] monk [[Hsuan Hua]] (''right'') are meditating in yogic posture. }} '''Meditation''' is a practice where an individual uses a technique - such as mindfulness, or focusing their mind on a particular object, thought or activity - to train attention and awareness, and achieve a mentally clear and emotionally calm state.{{rp|228–9}}{{rp|180}}{{rp|415}}{{rp|107}} Meditation has been practiced since [[history of meditation|antiquity]] in numerous religious traditions and beliefs. Since the 19th century, it has spread from its origins to other cultures where it is commonly practiced in private and business life. Meditation may be used with the aim of reducing stress, anxiety, depression, and pain, and increasing peace, perception,[https://hackspirit.com/dalai-lama-reveals-practice-meditation-properly/ For the 14th Dalai Lama the aim of meditation is "''to maintain a very full state of alertness and mindfulness, and then try to see the natural state of your consciousness.''"] [[self-concept]], and [[well-being]].{{cite web|url=https://nccih.nih.gov/health/meditation/overview.htm|title=Meditation: In Depth|website=NCCIH}}{{cite journal|pmc=4142584|year=2014|author1=Goyal|first1=M|title=Meditation Programs for Psychological Stress and Well-being: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis|journal=JAMA Internal Medicine|volume=174|issue=3|pages=357–368|last2=Singh|first2=S|last3=Sibinga|first3=E. M|last4=Gould|first4=N. F|last5=Rowland-Seymour|first5=A|last6=Sharma|first6=R|last7=Berger|first7=Z|last8=Sleicher|first8=D|last9=Maron|first9=D. D|last10=Shihab|first10=H. M|last11=Ranasinghe|first11=P. D|last12=Linn|first12=S|last13=Saha|first13=S|last14=Bass|first14=E. B|last15=Haythornthwaite|first15=J. A|doi=10.1001/jamainternmed.2013.13018|pmid=24395196}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0022167815594556 |title=Calm Abiding |journal=Journal of Humanistic Psychology |volume=57 |page=98 |year=2016 |last1=Shaner |first1=Lynne |last2=Kelly |first2=Lisa |last3=Rockwell |first3=Donna |last4=Curtis |first4=Devorah }}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2015.08.040 |title=Meditation and happiness: Mindfulness and self-compassion may mediate the meditation–happiness relationship |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=93 |pages=80–85 |year=2016 |last1=Campos |first1=Daniel |last2=Cebolla |first2=Ausiàs |last3=Quero |first3=Soledad |last4=Bretón-López |first4=Juana |last5=Botella |first5=Cristina |last6=Soler |first6=Joaquim |last7=García-Campayo |first7=Javier |last8=Demarzo |first8=Marcelo |last9=Baños |first9=Rosa María |hdl=10234/157867 }} Meditation is under [[research on meditation|research]] to define its possible health ([[psychology|psychological]], [[neurology|neurological]], and [[cardiovascular]]) and other effects. ==Etymology== The English ''meditation'' is derived from the [[Latin languages|Latin]] ''[[:wikt:meditatio|meditatio]]'', from a verb ''[[:wikt:meditor|meditari]]'', meaning "to think, contemplate, devise, ponder".''An universal etymological English dictionary'' 1773, London, by Nathan Bailey {{ISBN|1-00-237787-0}}. Note: from the 1773 edition on Google books, not earlier editions.{{Clarify|date=May 2011}} In the [[Old Testament]], ''hāgâ'' (Hebrew: ''הגה'') means to sigh or murmur, and also, to meditate.Terje Stordalen, "Ancient Hebrew Meditative Recitation", in Halvor Eifring (ed.), ''Meditation in Judaism, Christianity and Islam: Cultural Histories'', 2013, {{ISBN|978-1441122148}} pages 17-31 When the [[Hebrew Bible]] was translated into Greek, ''hāgâ'' became the Greek ''melete''. The Latin Bible then translated ''hāgâ''/''melete'' into ''meditatio''.''Christian spirituality: themes from the tradition'' by Lawrence S. Cunningham, Keith J. Egan 1996 {{ISBN|0-8091-3660-0}} page 88 The use of the term ''meditatio'' as part of a formal, stepwise process of meditation goes back to the 12th-century monk [[Guigo II]].''The Oblate Life'' by Gervase Holdaway, 2008 {{ISBN|0-8146-3176-2}} page 115 In addition within specific contexts more precise meanings are not uncommonly given the word "meditation".Besides Lectio and Yoga, examples include [[Herbert Benson]]'s (1975) ''Relaxation Response'' {{ISBN|0-380-00676-6}}, [[Jon Kabat-Zinn]]'s (1990) ''Full Catastrophe Living'' {{ISBN|0-385-29897-8}}, and [[Eknath Easwaran]]'s (1978) ''[[Passage Meditation]]'' {{ISBN|978-1-58638-026-7}} For example, "meditation" is sometimes the translation of ''meditatio'' in Latin. ''Meditatio'' is the second of four steps of ''[[Lectio Divina]]'', an ancient form of Christian prayer. "Meditation" also refers to the seventh of the eight limbs of [[Yoga]] in [[Patanjali]]'s ''[[Yoga Sutras]]'', a step called ''dhyāna'' in Sanskrit. Meditation refers to a mental or spiritual ''state'' that may be attained by such practices, and also refers to the ''practice'' of that state. Apart from its historical usage, the term ''meditation'' was introduced as a translation for Eastern spiritual practices, referred to as ''dhyāna'' [[Dhyana in Hinduism|in Hinduism]] and [[Buddhism]] and which comes from the [[Sanskrit]] root ''dhyai'', meaning to contemplate or meditate.[[Georg Feuerstein|Feuerstein, Georg]]. [http://www.santosha.com/moksha/meditation1.html "Yoga and Meditation (Dhyana)."] Moksha Journal. Issue 1. 2006. {{ISSN|1051-127X}}, {{OCLC|21878732}}The verb root "dhyai" is listed as referring to "contemplate, meditate on" and "dhyāna" is listed as referring to "meditation; religious contemplation" on page 134 of {{Cite book |title=A practical Sanskrit dictionary with transliteration, accentuation and etymological analysis throughout |last=Macdonell |first=Arthur Anthony |authorlink=Arthur Anthony Macdonell |date=1971 |origyear=Reprinted from 1929 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |location=London |isbn=|page=|url=|accessdate=}} The term "meditation" in English may also refer to practices from Islamic [[Sufism]],{{Cite book |title=The healing power of sufi meditation |last1=Mirahmadi |first1=Sayyid Nurjan |first2=Muhammad Nazim Adil al-Haqqani |last2=Naqshbandi |first3=Muhammad Hisham |last3=Kabbani |first4=Hedieh |last4=Mirahmadi |date=2005 |publisher=Naqshbandi Haqqani Sufi Order of America |location=Fenton, MI |isbn=978-1-930409-26-2 |page=|url=https://www.loc.gov/catdir/toc/ecip057/2005001975.html |accessdate=}} or other traditions such as Jewish [[Kabbalah]] and Christian [[Hesychasm]].{{Cite book |title=The meditative mind: The varieties of meditative experience |last=Goleman |first=Daniel |authorlink=Daniel Goleman |year=1988 |publisher=Tarcher |location=New York |isbn=978-0-87477-833-5 |url=}} An edited book about "meditation" published in 2003, for example, included chapter contributions by authors describing Hindu, Buddhist, Taoist, Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions.{{Cite book |title=The experience of meditation: Experts introduce the major traditions |editor=Jonathan Shear |year=2006 |publisher=Paragon House |location=St. Paul, MN |isbn=978-1-55778-857-3 |pages=|doi=|url=https://www.loc.gov/catdir/toc/ecip066/2005037743.html }}{{Cite journal |author=Joel Stein |year=2003 |title=Just say Om |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |volume=162 |issue=5 |pages=48–56 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1005349,00.html |doi=|pmid=}} In the print edition (pp. 54-55), the "Through the Ages" box describes "Christian Meditation", "Cabalistic (Jewish) Meditation", "Muslim Meditation", and others. Scholars have noted that "the term 'meditation' as it has entered contemporary usage" is parallel to the term "contemplation" in Christianity,{{Cite book |author=Jean L. Kristeller |year=2010 |chapter=Spiritual engagement as a mechanism of change in mindfulness- and acceptance-based therapies |editor1=Ruth A. Baer |editor2=Kelly G. Wilson |title=Assessing mindfulness and acceptance processes in clients: Illuminating the theory and practice of change |location=Oakland, CA |publisher=New Harbinger |pages=152–184 |isbn=978-1-57224-694-2 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=8K41STQ06MMC&pg=PA162&dq=isbn:9781572246942+easwaran+passage&q=isbn%3A9781572246942%20easwaran%20passage |doi=|pmid=}}. Page 161 states "In Christianity, the term 'contemplation' is parallel to the term 'meditation' as it has entered contemporary usage" but in many cases, practices similar to modern forms of meditation were simply called "prayer". Christian, Judaic, and Islamic forms of meditation are typically devotional, scriptural or thematic, while Asian forms of meditation are often more purely technical.Halvor Eifring, "Meditation in Judaism, Christianity and Islam: Technical Aspects of Devotional Practices", in Halvor Eifring (ed.), ''Meditation in Judaism, Christianity and Islam: Cultural Histories'', 2013, {{ISBN|978-1441122148}} pages 1-16. ==Definitions== In popular usage, the word "meditation" and the phrase "meditative practice" are often used imprecisely to designate broadly similar practices, or sets of practices, that are found across many cultures and traditions.{{Cite journal |author=Mary Carroll |year=2005 |title=Divine therapy: Teaching reflective and meditative practices |journal=Teaching Theology and Religion |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=232–238 |url=|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9647.2005.00249.x |pmid=}} Definitions in the Oxford and Cambridge living dictionaries and Merriam-Webster include both the original Latin meaning of "think[ing] deeply about (something)," as the popular usage of "to focus one's mind for a period of time,"{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/meditate|title=meditate - Definition of meditate in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English}} "the act of giving your attention to only one thing,"{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/meditation|title=meditation Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary|website=dictionary.cambridge.org}} and "to engage in mental exercise (such as concentration on one's breathing or repetition of a mantra) for the purpose of reaching a heightened level of spiritual awareness."{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/meditate|title=Definition of meditate|publisher=Merriam-Webster Dictionary|language=en|date=18 December 2017|accessdate=25 December 2017}} What is considered meditation can include almost any practice that trains the attention or teaches calm or compassion.{{cite web|url=http://brainimaging.waisman.wisc.edu/~lutz/Meditation_Neuroscience_2005_AL_JDD_RJD_2.pdf|title=Lutz A., Dunne J.D., Davidson R.J. Meditation and the Neuroscience of Consciousness: an Introduction in Cambridge Handbook of Consciousness edited by Zelazo P., Moscovitch M. and Thompson E. (2007)|publisher=}} Bond et al. (2009), based on views common to seven experts trained in diverse but empirically highly studied (clinical or Eastern-derived,) forms of meditation,"members were chosen on the basis of their publication record of research on the therapeutic use of meditation, their knowledge of and training in traditional or clinically developed meditation techniques, and their affiliation with universities and research centers.. Each member had specific expertise and training in at least one of the following meditation practices: [[kundalini yoga]], [[Transcendental Meditation]], relaxation response, [[mindfulness-based stress reduction]], and [[vipassana]] meditation" (Bond, Ospina et al., 2009, p. 131); their views were combined using "the [[Delphi method|Delphi technique]]... a method of eliciting and refining group judgments to address complex problems with a high level of uncertainty" (p. 131). identified {{quote|three main criteria [...] as essential to any meditation practice: the use of a defined technique, logic relaxation, and a self-induced state/mode. Other criteria deemed important [but not essential] involve a state of psychophysical relaxation, the use of a self-focus skill or anchor, the presence of a state of suspension of logical thought processes, a religious/spiritual/philosophical context, or a state of mental silence.{{Cite journal |year=2009 |title=Defining a complex intervention: The development of demarcation criteria for "meditation" |journal=[[Psychology of Religion and Spirituality]]|volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=129–137 |doi=10.1037/a0015736 |author1=Kenneth Bond |author2=Maria B. Ospina |author3=Nicola Hooton |author4=Liza Bialy |author5=Donna M. Dryden |author6=Nina Buscemi |author7=David Shannahoff-Khalsa |author8=Jeffrey Dusek |author9=Linda E. Carlson}}{{rp|135}} [...] It is plausible that meditation is best thought of as a natural category of techniques best captured by '[[family resemblance]]s' [...] or by the related [[Prototype (linguistics)|'prototype' model of concepts]]."''{{rp|135}}The full quotation from Bond, Ospina et al. (2009, p. 135) reads: ''"It is plausible that meditation is best thought of as a natural category of techniques best captured by '[[family resemblance]]s' ([[Ludwig Wittgenstein|Wittgenstein]], 1968) or by the related [[Prototype (linguistics)|'prototype' model of concepts]] ([[Eleanor Rosch|Rosch]], 1973; [[Eleanor Rosch|Rosch]] & Mervin, 1975)."''}} The table shows several other definitions of meditation that have been used by influential modern reviews of research on meditation across multiple traditions. {| style="border:1px solid darkgrey; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; font-size:90%; width:100%; max-width:64em;" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="10" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|'''Definitions or Characterizations of Meditation:
Examples from Prominent Reviews'''* |-valign="top" |Definition / Characterization |Review |- valign="top" |style="width: 24em" |• "[M]editation refers to a family of self-regulation practices that focus on training attention and awareness in order to bring mental processes under greater voluntary control and thereby foster general mental well-being and development and/or specific capacities such as calm, clarity, and concentration"{{rp|228–9}} |style="width: 8em" |Walsh & Shapiro (2006) |- valign="top" |• "''[M]editation'' is used to describe practices that self-regulate the body and mind, thereby affecting mental events by engaging a specific attentional set.... regulation of attention is the central commonality across the many divergent methods"{{rp|180}} |Cahn & Polich (2006) |- valign="top" |• "We define meditation... as a stylized mental technique... repetitively practiced for the purpose of attaining a subjective experience that is frequently described as very restful, silent, and of heightened alertness, often characterized as blissful"{{rp|415}} |Jevning et al. (1992) |- valign="top" |• "the need for the meditator to retrain his attention, whether through concentration or mindfulness, is the single invariant ingredient in... every meditation system"{{rp|107}} |Goleman (1988) |- valign="top" | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|*Influential reviews encompassing ''multiple'' methods of meditation (The first 3 are cited >80 times in [[PsycINFO]].Number of citations in [[PsycINFO]]: 254 for Walsh & Shapiro, 2006 (26 August 2018); 561 for Cahn & Polich, 2006 (26 August 2018); 83 for Jevning et al. (1992) (26 August 2018). Goleman's [[The Varieties of the Meditative Experience|book]] has 33 editions listed in WorldCat: 17 editions as ''[https://www.worldcat.org/title/meditative-mind-the-varieties-of-meditative-experience-daniel-goleman/oclc/868744343/editions?editionsView=true The meditative mind: The varieties of meditative experience]'' and 16 editions as ''[https://www.worldcat.org/title/varieties-of-the-meditative-experience/oclc/636007220/editions?editionsView=true The varieties of meditative experience].'' Citation and edition counts are as of August 2018 and September 2018 respectively.) |} {{-}} In modern psychological research, meditation has been defined and characterized in a variety of ways; many of these emphasize the role of [[attention]].{{Cite journal |author=Roger Walsh |author-link=Roger Walsh |author2=Shauna L. Shapiro|last-author-amp=yes |year=2006 |title=The meeting of meditative disciplines and western psychology: A mutually enriching dialogue |journal=American Psychologist |volume=61 |issue=3 |pages=227–239 |url=http://www.escholarship.org/uc/item/7885t0n6|doi=10.1037/0003-066X.61.3.227 |issn=0003-066X |pmid=16594839|format=Submitted manuscript }}{{Cite journal |author1=B. Rael Cahn |author2=John Polich |year=2006 |title=Meditation states and traits: EEG, ERP, and neuroimaging studies |journal=[[Psychological Bulletin]] |volume=132 |issue=2 |pages=180–211 |url=|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.132.2.180 |issn=0033-2909 |pmid=16536641}}{{Cite journal |author1=R. Jevning |author2=R. K. Wallace |author3=M. Beidebach |year=1992 |title=The physiology of meditation: A review: A wakeful hypometabolic integrated response |journal=Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=415–424 |url=|doi=10.1016/S0149-7634(05)80210-6 |issn=|pmid=1528528 }} Scientific reviews have proposed that researchers attempt to more clearly define the type of meditation being practiced in order that the results of their studies be made clearer.Lutz, Dunne and Davidson, "Meditation and the Neuroscience of Consciousness: An Introduction" in ''The Cambridge handbook of consciousness'' by Philip David Zelazo, Morris Moscovitch, Evan Thompson, 2007 {{ISBN|0-521-85743-0}} page 499-551 [http://compassion.stanford.edu/pdf/Dunne_Ch%2019%20Lutz%20Dunne%20Davidson-1.pdf (proof copy)] (NB: pagination of published was 499-551 proof was 497-550). {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303102034/http://compassion.stanford.edu/pdf/Dunne_Ch%2019%20Lutz%20Dunne%20Davidson-1.pdf |date=March 3, 2012 }}{{rp|499}} One review of the field provides a detailed set of questions as a starting point in reaching this goal. The practitioner of meditation attempts to get beyond the reflexive, "thinking" mindThis does not mean that all meditation seeks to take a person beyond ''all'' thought processes, only those processes that are sometimes referred to as "discursive" or "logical" (see Shapiro, 1982/1984; Bond, Ospina, et al., 2009; Appendix B, pp. 279-282 in Ospina, Bond, et al., 2007). (sometimes called "discursive thinking"An influential definition by Shapiro (1982) states that "''meditation refers to a family of techniques which have in common a conscious attempt to focus attention in a nonanalytical way and an attempt not to dwell on discursive, ruminating thought''" (p. 6, italics in original); the term "discursive thought" has long been used in Western philosophy, and is often viewed as a synonym to logical thought ({{cite book |title=Reading neoplatonism : Non-discursive thinking in the texts of plotinus, proclus, and damascius |last=Rappe|first=Sara|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge; New York|isbn=978-0-521-65158-5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=_DrXt-7UGkkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn=9780521651585#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=}}). or "logic"Bond, Ospina et al. (2009) – see fuller discussion elsewhere on this page -- report that 7 expert scholars who had studied different traditions of meditation agreed that an "essential" component of meditation "Involves logic relaxation: not 'to intend' to analyze the possible psychophysical effects, not 'to intend' to judge the possible results, not 'to intend' to create any type of expectation regarding the process" (p. 134, Table 4). In their final consideration, all 7 experts regarded this feature as an "essential" component of meditation; none of them regarded it as merely "important but not essential" (p. 234, Table 4). (This same result is presented in Table B1 in Ospina, Bond, et al., 2007, p. 281)) This may be to achieve a deeper, more devout, or more relaxed state. In this article the terms "meditative practice" and "meditation" are mostly used in this broad sense. However, in some contexts more specialized meanings of "meditation" may be intended. ===Separation of technique from tradition=== Some of the difficulty in precisely defining meditation has been the difficulty in recognizing the particularities of the many various traditions. There may be differences between the theories of one tradition of meditation as to what it means to practice meditation.{{cite web|title=John Dunne's speech |url=http://ccare.stanford.edu/node/21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120171057/http://ccare.stanford.edu/node/21 |archivedate=November 20, 2012 }} The differences between the various traditions themselves, which have grown up a great distance apart from each other, may be even starker. Taylor noted that to refer only to meditation from a particular faith (e.g., "Hindu" or "Buddhist") {{quote|''...is not enough, since the cultural traditions from which a particular kind of meditation comes are quite different and even within a single tradition differ in complex ways. The specific name of a school of thought or a teacher or the title of a specific text is often quite important for identifying a particular type of meditation.''{{rp|2}} }} Ornstein noted that ''"Most techniques of meditation do not exist as solitary practices but are only artificially separable from an entire system of practice and belief."''Robert Ornstein (1972, originally published 1971), in: Naranjo and Orenstein, ''On the Psychology of Meditation''. New York: Viking.
